October 29, 1951.

Mr. D. Hett,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Lytton, B.C.,

We have the September Quarterly Return and Form I.A. 411 for the St. George's Indian Residential School.

It is noted that forty new pupils were admitted to the school while no application has been made for discharges. The number of pupils for whom 62 days grant was claimed adds up to 33. If all of the 33 pupils for whom 62 days grant was claimed were discharged, the enrolment for the school would be increased by at least seven pupils.

Attached is a copy of a letter forwarded Canon Hives on September 11 asking him to limit his total enrolment to 190 pupils which is the authorized enrolment for the school.

We have received a large number of applications for admission for pupils in the Nicola Agency and your Agency. On checking with the Return it is noted that these pupils are already in the school and entered on the September Return. The Principal has calculated the average for the September Return to be 211 which is 21 over the authorized enrolment. Would you kindly contact Canon Hives and advise this office on what authority he admitted pupils to the St. George's school without having their admissions approved and knowing that his average would exceed the authorized enrolment.
I am forwarding you an extra copy of this letter should you wish to forward it to Canon Hives.

We are withholding approval of admission of the pupils from your Agency and the Nicola Agency until we hear from you.

Would you kindly indicate the religious denomination on the attached applications.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

MFT/HM

Encl:
October 30, 1951.

Mr. D.M. Hett,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Lytton, B.C.,

With reference to the September Return for the St. George's Indian Residential School, we do not appear to have any information on pupils 521, 597 and 598.

It is presumed that these are re-admissions, however, no indication to that effect was made either in the "Remarks" column of the Return or Form I.A. III.

We have a letter of October 18 from Canon Hives requesting the discharge of a number of pupils. It would be appreciated if you would advise Reverend Hives that a request for future discharges should be indicated on Form I.A. III. When the entries are made on this form, it is easier to check our records when any information is required in future.

We do not appear to have any applications for the admission of the following pupils: 0501, 0503, 615, 616 and 0487. It would be appreciated if you would forward these.

Time of day: 10 a.m.

M.D.
Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am just starting up again. This is my first day in my office since coming out of hospital, where I had to undergo a major operation. My first letter is to you in reference to the letter, 388-10 to Mr. Hott, Superintendent at Lytton. I am sorry that my health has hindered proper supervision of admission and discharge of pupils.

In the recent quarterly returns from St. George's School, there was a large turnover of pupils. No matter how carefully I try to arrange things so that I may know a little before-hand what new pupils we are likely to have, I can never be sure just what is going to take place until the day of school opening at the beginning of September. Of late years they have come crowding in, and I have had to turn many away. Then, because children come in, who are either too far distant from any school, or who come from broken homes, I have to sort out those in school, whose parents can reasonably be expected to care for them and send them to a Public School, in order to make room for the more urgent cases.

A few years ago I wrote you a letter showing my concern on account of the financial situation; and how difficult it was to make ends meet. In reply you said the only remedy was a full school. With that object in view, I have taken the sewing-room from the top floor of the main building, and have turned them into dormitories, as per original plan. I applied for and received last Summer twenty new beds; and we now have the same dormitory space and accommodation as Alert Bay, where they have, I believe, a pupilage of 220. The only possible way that we can carry on here is to have a full school, and receive a grant allowance for every child in school. The same staff is required for 100 as for 220. The same heating and lighting expenses. Last year we received a grant allowance for an average of 304.5 pupils all through the year. I do sincerely hope that we may be allowed a full school. Dr. Tennant was here a few weeks ago, and seemed to satisfied with the dormitory space allowed for the pupils. If I have to discharge pupils down to the pupilage 100, it will be a very great disappointment to the people, and a disgrace to us.

There was some mention about pupil No. 527, Donald Adams. Previous to last year this boy attended St. George's School. He was sent to Edmonton last year, and, from what I can make out, did not do very well. Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield sent him back to us, and he was given his old number.

The explanation for the two Application Forms enclosed is as follows: The deceased father of the two children was a Catholic, the mother an old pupil of St. George's School. The children were found
in a state of neglect by the brother of the deceased father, who adopted them and brought them here. This man is an Anglican, and has three children here.

I think it is to be regretted that this and similar matters could not be disposed of from the Commissioner's office in Vancouver. We seldom ever see any official here, and you are so far away. But there are times when even important officials from Ottawa come, and drive through Lytton without bothering to call on us. They could, at least call and give a word of encouragement.

Now, I suppose the balance of the Quarterly grant allowance will be held up until this matter is settled. We have less than nothing in the bank, and many bills to pay. I do hope you will, as I think you always have, try to do your best for us.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal

August 9th 1951

Dear Miss Wilson,

The days for our children's holiday are nearing the end very quickly as it seems and we must prepare them for their return. The first thing that I want to know is: are you having an escort for the northern children and what direction are they taking to return to school after their vacation? Last year we waited for them expecting them to return by boat and rail but they took the interior route. Second we have a young one Elizabeth Margaret Mahoney aged 7 years that we wish to enter with Emma and Gloria soon. We wrote a letter just before the other children came out about these children but have received no reply as of today. And what day will the northern children if they return by steamship leave Prince Rupert south bound so that we may put our children on this boat. And the registration papers that we sign for entry we wish to have sent here then we could fill them and forward the escort or mail to you.

I wishing you and yours the best of health and may God bless you all.

Yours Truly,
Raymond Mahoney
August 14, 1951

Mr. Raymond Nahanees,
Namu Cannery,
Namu, B.C.

Dear Raymond:

I have your letter of the 9th inst., re. your girls. The boat, returning with the Prince Rupert pupils, will leave P. Rupert on Sept. 4th. The children will be under the supervision of Mr. Anfield, Indian Superintendent at Prince Rupert, who will escort them to Vancouver.

I am enclosing an application form for your daughter Elizabeth. In regard to Leonie I consider it was a great pity that she was taken from the Roman Catholic school and sent to us. I know this may appear strange for me to say this, but she had, I presume, spent some years under the sisters. They simply made a good Catholic of her during those years, and she will always be one at heart for the rest of her life. That is my sincere conviction of the matter. For her own peace of mind and future welfare and happiness, I think, Raymond, that you should send her to a Roman Catholic convent. And as I say this, I speak as one father to another. I am an Anglican, and nobody could change me from that status, but I do love children, and every child who comes to me is my child. And so, Raymond, I would again urge on you to give Leona back to the Church that she really, at heart belongs.

The other two girls, I will gladly take in, and do everything possible for them.

Kindest regards and every good wish.

Dear Mr. Taylor:

Owing to illness, I was unable to keep my promise to meet you last Thursday in reference to Leona Nehnsee. We have, at present, two girls, sisters of the above. In answer to a letter from the father, asking me to find a position for Leona, who was supposed to be of age to leave school, I told him it would be far better for him to place her in a convent, as she was, at heart, because of her early training, a Roman Catholic girl. He then asked me if I could do with the younger girl. I told him we could take in two of his girls. He therefore sent the two younger than Leona. We have a very full school; more than we should have, and unless the Department give us a full per capita grant allowance for all we have in school, I don't see how we are going to pay all the bills that come in.

I am afraid I shall not be able to get into Vancouver for some weeks, as I have to go into hospital on Wednesday to undergo a fairly serious operation.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Pupil No. 0408, Joyce Brown: This pupil, who comes from Hazelton, has turned seventeen years of age. Her sister, who lives in Seattle writes, asking if she may go to be near her. She says she has no difficulty in obtaining a position as a domestic in a good home. The girl, herself, is anxious to go. She is from Hazelton, and I am firmly of the opinion that if she goes home to Hazelton, she will not have the ghost of a chance to keep straight. Her mother has a poor record, and she lives with a man who has a worse record.

The Superintendent at Hazelton is a new man, and would not know much about the girl.

I am enclosing a letter in answer to one I wrote to the girl's sister.

I would recommend that this pupil be allowed to go to her sister. I would see that she is properly outfitted with clothes etc., and see that she meets her sister in Vancouver, if my recommendation meets with your approval. February 6, 1929.

Dear Mr. Bitchburn:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to manual training at the Indian schools of British Columbia. I am very desirous of getting this activity extended without delay, and, as a preliminary step, I have to authorise you to purchase the materials listed on the enclosure you forwarded. The materials for work benches, the individual and general sets of tools and the drawing sets indicated should be supplied to the Skeetches, Squamish, Upper Island, Cariboo, St. Mary's, St. George's, Alert Bay, and Fraser Lake schools. As the Skeetches activity can be started immediately, work benches, drawing sets, etc., may be purchased. For Squamish you may supply $450 worth of equipment, as listed in your letter. The department is already in correspondence with the Reverend Mr. Scott concerning suitable workrooms for St. George's. I rely upon you to purchase to the best advantage and to write to the principals concerned explaining the use to which this equipment will be put. You may also authorise each principal to purchase lumber with which to work, as soon as the classes can be started. You may fix the amount to be expended on these materials from $600 to $1,100 as indicated in your letter, and you should direct principals to make requisition to the Indians agent for further materials, when required. If you find that any expenditure is necessary to complete the carpenter shop at Fraser Lake you should let the department have an estimate.

I have written a special letter to Father Monk of the Cariboo School, pointing out that the department not be overworked in connection with the supply of fuel, and I am satisfied that vocational training can be started at this institution also. The building is being insured to assist with current financing, and I have clearly indicated that the extra grant is for the engaging of labour for the supply of fuel.

The question of organising this work and the appointment or securing of suitable instructors should now engage our attention. If we could secure the

Ottawa, May 14, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is making special efforts to improve the instruction in manual and vocational training for boys in the Indian schools of British Columbia. If this phase of our educational programme can be made more effective, it will greatly benefit the Indians of the province. Most residential schools have a workshop or other space that can be used for vocational training. If you can improve the workshop facilities should be taken at the St. George's Indian Residential School, please cooperate with Mr. Indian Agent Graham with a view to making a recommendation to the Department.

A thorough course in carpentry is the present aim. To this end, Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn has been authorized to supply benches and tools and there has been directed to you a text on manual training, job sheets in woodworking and a publication on how to work with tools and wood. Further, you have been authorized to present to Mr. Agent Graham reasonable accounts for materials with which to work.

The Department is desirous of having a qualified instructor for this work at all schools where this special training is being undertaken. Some schools have on the staff an officer who is well qualified for the activity and who can be released from other duties for the manual training classes. I understand there are summer courses for instructors in manual training in Vancouver and Victoria. Other Indian schools are so situated that they can secure the services of instructors from municipal schools. In this case, classes are held two or three times per week. The Department would like to know what arrangements you have made, or can make, for this important work. Do not hesitate to enlist the cooperation of Mr. Graham, if the Department can be of any assistance.

At a later date, it is hoped to extend the vocational training to include gas engines and other machinery; and whenever you believe this additional course should be given at the St. George's Indian Residential School, you will please inform the Department. A copy of this letter is being directed to Mr. Agent Graham for his information.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Mclean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B. C.
Dear Sir-

I note with extreme interest the propositions of the Dept., regarding manual training and the possibility of gas engines and other machinery coming under their Dept in the schools. We could to a degree carry on this latter at the present time if a shop were available.

The manual training and repair shops are now under course of construction but these do not include a shop wherein we could put in our own trucks and engines for repair.

We need a machine shed wherein to house our farm machinery and a shop in connection with this building would be the proper place for the engine repair shop.

It is a step which will prove of great benefit to the Indian work in this province and a great boon to the schools.

I shall put forth every effort to utilize the Dept in their endeavor.

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

Principal
St Georges Residential School

Dear Mr. Graham,

Referring to that part of the Ass. Dep. & Secretary's letter of May the 14th numbering 168-9-11 end of which you have a copy, please note that I am to enlist your help in carrying the proposed new phase of work in our school.

In connection therewith I might say that I have been able to secure the services of a competent man who has qualified for this work in Victoria and as it is a new phase in the school education and one in which I heartily concur, it is adding an extra salary of approximately $30.00 per month to the present amount paid by the school in salaries. Do you think the Dept would be satisfied to allow me a cash salary of $80.00 over and above the present per capita grants allowing me to take care of the remainder in the way of benefits such as vegetables, fuel, etc. I would gladly accept this help as the financing of the school is by no means an easy task.

I have also to say that I have on the staff now a man who could handle the gas engine work spoken of by the Ass. Dep. and would like to start this work immediately or as soon as possible but this work will entail a building in which to house our blacksmithing equipment which is still at the old site and several of the tools have since we moved away been stolen. It is essential that we should move this shop as quickly as we can to save the property of the Dept. and have same near at hand to do our repair work and teach the boys. The Gas Engine shop should be in this building and if the Dept. can see fit to give us the lumber I can safely say that we can undertake the building of same with our own help under the supervision of Mr Leonard, the Manual instructor who is a carpenter by trade.

We also have no machine shed in which to house the farm implements. Up to the present we have been housing them in every available tumble down shack, these are becoming more dilapidated as the years go by and now are almost as good as nothing. If the lumber were available we could also erect this building ourselves, not only saving the Dept. the cost of labor but would also give the older boys some needed practical training.

The training in the Manual room must in this part of Canada lead up to the Building trade and the more actual work the boys can receive here the better for them.

I trust you will see fit to take these requirements to the Dept. asking them to do what they can to aid us in the same.

Yours very obediently

[Signature]

Principal
Sir:

On May 15th, the Department addressed a letter to the Rev. Principal of St. George's Residential School, in connection with making a special effort to improve manual and vocational training in schools of British Columbia. A copy of Department's letter was sent to me, asking for my co-operation.

I have gone into this matter thoroughly with the Rev. Principal, and am now enclosing a copy of a letter just received from him, together with plans for a new machine and blacksmith shop, along an implement shed, which is fully explained in the Rev. Principal's letter.

The actual cost of the material for these buildings would amount to $200 or $300, and if this work is to be carried on this building is very essential, as the present blacksmith shop, which is really inadequate, being too small, and an old building, is situated at the site of the old school, which is at least half a mile from the present school.

The implement shed is greatly needed, as at the present time, all farm machinery is scattered in old buildings in all parts of the farm. The most of these buildings are falling down.

I would like to recommend that the material for these buildings asked for be supplied.

The wages to be paid to a manual training teacher will come rather hard on the Principal, and I would like to recommend that the Department make a special grant for this.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, September 19, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School regarding manual and vocational training at this school. The sketch drawings of the new machine and blacksmith shop and implement shed, with estimate of the cost of the material to erect same which he states is required to properly carry out the manual training instruction, and the need in providing an implement shed, have been noted.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding approximately $1,000 in the purchase of the building material required to erect a machine and blacksmith shop, also an implement shed. This building material should be purchased to the best advantage, and certified accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost should be forwarded by you in the usual manner. It is to be understood that the labour in erecting the buildings will be performed by school help under the supervision of the manual training instructor without cost to the Department.

Relative to the Principal's request that this Department provide part of the salary of the manual training instructor, I have to say that the sum of $40 per month will be allowed for this purpose. This will be paid upon receipt of certified vouchers from you from time to time for the amount due at the above rate.

The expenditure in supplying the building material and also the grant allowed towards payment of the salary of the instructor will be made from "Special Grant", and you should so state on your vouchers.

In erecting the machine and blacksmith shop and implement shed, care should be taken to see that proper sites for these buildings are selected, and while at convenient points they should not detract from the general appearance of the other buildings.

Your obedient servant,

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR G.H. BARRY,
DATED FEBRUARY 19, 1931, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE
ST. GEORGE'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Original on File 165-0-6.

Mr. Batchelor has a Temporary Manual Training Certificate from Vancouver.

There are 65 boys in this class. They work in groups. The room has 8 very good benches with room for 16 boys. The Provincial Course adapted to local conditions is followed and the boys enjoy their work.

There is an excellent supply of the necessary tools. These are well looked after by the teacher and the boys. A large number of the articles made are used in the school. The boys are building a First Aid Room and making the furniture for it.
Dear Mr. Ferrier,

We are in receipt of your circular of the 19th inst., No. 1-11, and note your suggestions. We are able to carry out the greater part of these in detail, excepting perhaps for the butter making for girls.

We are at the present time feeding milk to the children, and while they are here we are not separating so we handle all the whole milk in the school, but the time is not far hence when we shall be obliged to do continual separating and this will mean a new cream separator and some other equipment such as churn and other utensils to be used for butter making. We shall be glad when the time comes to give this instruction if the Department will equip us with these necessities in the dairy.

We have also been able to give some instruction in gas engines, having the building fairly well equipped; in order that this should become a course of instruction it will be necessary for us to have a special man for the work and unless the Department is prepared to accept the responsibility of a full salaried instructor it will not be possible to employ such a man, paying him at the per capita grant.

I agree with you, and I have heretofore and up to the present time, made it my business to carry members of the staff, both inside and out, who are in every way capable of scientific instruction. These people, if efficient, demand a fairly high wage. With the present financial condition, is it possible to employ this extra man?

I trust you will see fit in the near future to be able to allow us the needed equipment, and also the extra salaried man. When the Department is ready to do this I shall be pleased to put this instruction into action as I realise the necessity for a thorough training for the equipping of the children to enable them to take care of themselves when they return to the reserves and make homes for themselves.

I trust you will be able to make it possible for us to carry out the wishes of the Department.

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]

PRINCIPAL.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa, February 1, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received a report from Mr. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, on the vocational training being carried out by the pupils of St. George's Indian Residential School. He states that, while the course followed is that approved for use in the provincial schools, too much attention is being paid to the actual scientific work of manual training. He also states he discussed this matter with Mr. John Kyle, Organizer of Technical Instruction for the Provincial Department of Education, and that they both agree that in Indian schools it is a mistake to keep the boys at such elementary work for a lengthy period. They feel it would be much better to show them how to use the tools, and then to put them to the actual construction of useful articles. Mr. Barry states that he explained this to Mr. Batchelor, the Instructor at the school.

The Department is not prepared to furnish an electric lathe and band saw. Mr. Kyle, who is an expert on manual training, and whose opinion is of value, has pointed out that the use of lathes and band saws are not what is wanted in the teaching of manual training. He is of opinion that the boys ought to be taught the use of tools which they will be using when they leave school.

The Department will place an order with the Government Stationery Office here to supply asbestoslate blackboard, 12' x 4', as recommended by Inspector Barry for use in the manual training shop.

You may arrange to purchase a quantity of lumber for the construction of drawing benches, to a cost not exceeding approximately $15. It is understood that the boys will be able to make these benches if the lumber is supplied. After the purchase has been made, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B.C.
Vocational Training:

The girls are learning to cook, and to do all the ordinary house work. There are in the sewing-room nine ordinary Singer sewing machines and two of the larger Singer tailor machines. The girls learn to use these machines in due course. They learn to sew, patch, darn, and as they grow older they make some of their own dresses and other clothes.

The Manual Training is under Mr. Batchelor. This teacher has a Temporary Manual Training Certificate from the Provincial Dept. of Education, as he has taken, and will complete his training, in the Vancouver Summer School for Manual Training Teachers. There are 65 boys in this class. They work in groups. The Manual Training shop has eight very good dual benches.

While it is true that the course followed is that approved for use in the Provincial Schools, as previously reported when I first inspected this school, it is also true that too much attention is being paid to the actual scientific work of Manual Training. It will no doubt be noted that this is the exact opposite of the conditions in the majority of the Indian Residential Schools. Since my inspection of this school, I have had a long talk with the Organizer of Vocational Instruction in British Columbia, a Mr. John Kyle, of the Department of Education, in Victoria.

The display from this school at the Canadian Pacific Exhibition in Vancouver was as I reported at the time much below the standard of either Alert Bay or Coqualeetza Indian Residential Schools.

I am informed that the Manual Training class here at Lytton has been following the course set for the Vancouver City schools. Mr. Kyle and I agree that in Indian schools it is a mistake to keep the boys at such elementary work for a lengthy time. It is we feel much better to show them how to use the tools, and then put them to the actual construction of useful articles.

I have explained some of this to the Instructor, Mr. Batchelor, and think that there will be a definite improvement in the work at St. Joseph's before long.

A number of articles have been made for use in the school. These include tables, cupboards, a High School Laboratory Cabinet, and a number of smaller articles.

The tools are in excellent condition, and everything is well looked after by the teacher. In fact the Manual Training here is a very definite part of the school work.

A Green Kiloplate Board 12 feet by 4 feet is strongly recommended for use in the Manual Training Shop. I also wish to recommend the supply of about £15.00 worth of lumber for the construction of Drawing Benches. The boys will be able to make these if they have the required lumber.

The Principal and Mr. Batchelor also wish for an Electric Lathe and for an Electric Band Saw. While I was perfectly willing to recommend these, if they would be for the benefit of the boys, I spoke about it to Mr. Kyle. Mr. Kyle is of course an expert on Manual Training, and his opinion is of value. He pointed out to me that the use of Lathes and Band Saws was not what was needed in the teaching of Manual Training. He thought that the boys ought to be taught the use of the tools which they will be using when they leave school. I am therefore not prepared to recommend the supply of the above mentioned Lathe and Band-Saw at the present time.

All the above Vocational Work is of definite use to the boys and girls when they leave school. It is making a difference to life in the Indian villages, as the children leaving school insist on changes being made in their homes to conform more or less with the conditions under which they have lived in the Residential Schools.

Russell T. Perrier Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of February last (No. 165-0-11) Inspector Barry has evidently been impressed by an argument which he and I had over Exhibition work displayed at the Vancouver Exhibition last autumn. I pointed out to him that I felt the work exhibited by these Schools was far in excess of work which should be done for the length of time the Manual Training course has become a factor in our School Education. I thought there was too much highly polished furniture and not enough elementary work on exhibit. Again, I pointed out that with only two boys in St. George's School who were over fifteen years of age it was a physical impossibility for us to compete with classes ranging in number from ten to twenty. I also pointed out to him that we had too much other work in Manual Training for the boys to do without confining our whole year to Exhibition work.

I am sure you can readily see for yourself by the enclosed list of Manual Training Room production that we are not confining ourselves to those courses stipulated by the Organiser of Technical Education. We are using tin models only in which to acquaint the boys with the tools, then branching out into heavier and more practical work.

This year I have mapped out a course for the Manual Training shop which includes building of irrigation flumes, making of gates, making rustic chairs etc. etc. This I think is much more practical for the boys of this district and much more valuable to them, than the making of highly polished furniture.

We shall be working on the butcher's shop shortly, and this will help to increase their knowledge of building.
St. George's Indian Residential School
Originated by the New England Company
(The oldest English Missionary Society, founded 1649)

Lytton, B.C.

R.T.Ferrier Esq: -2- 19.2.32

I trust that the foregoing, together with the enclosed list will serve to show that Inspector Barry placed altogether too much emphasis on our talk of Exhibition production. If the Exhibition of last year is what is expected of these Schools then St. George's is out of the running for some years to come, as boys of fourteen and fifteen cannot produce the workmanship of lads running in age from eighteen to twenty. But if we are recognised in comparison of age grade, then we can hope to do something.

Very obediently yours,

A.R.LETT

September 22nd., 1932.

Dear Sir:-

In accordance with instructions received, I beg to submit herewith report on St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton Agency.

Rev. A.R. Lett, Principal of St. George's Residential School, was away at the time of my visit. I regret to report that this gentleman, unfortunately, has been in ill health, but I understand he is now better again.

There were 160 children in the school at the time of my visit. The school was clean and tidy. Fire drill is carried out regularly, the time for getting the children out at the last alarm being 2½ minutes. The chemical extinguishers have been filled lately, and I instructed that the hose pipes should be tested.

The children were having stew, potatoes and apple pie for their next meal.

The crops looked very promising. Good manual training is being continued. A good store cupboard is required for the keeping of the carpenter tools in the manual training shop. Cost of material would be about $15.00, and I should suggest that this be authorized.

Yours truly,

FEB 28 1933

Mr. A. Strang,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr. Strang:

In your note, dated yesterday, numbering 1361-06, regarding the bill presented to you from Mr. Fred Meyers, amounting to $55.37, in which the Department says there is no authority given by the Department for the purchase of this material.

In regard to this bill, as it included necessary material to carry on the work in the Manual Training Shop for the School year, 1932-1933, I have to refer you to letter number 165-C-11 dated May 14th 1929, in which the Department states the following:

"Further, you have been authorised to present to Mr. Agent Graham, reasonable accounts for materials with which to work."

and again:

"Do not hesitate to enlist the co-operation of Mr. Graham if the Department can be of any assistance."

Heretofore, this has been done without any criticism at all from the Department, and, as this account was for material at the beginning of the term, the bill for which unfortunately was overlooked, there seems to be no reason why the Department should make any objection to paying this bill. As stated above, permission was given to me direct from the Department, under signature of J. D. McLean, assistant Deputy and Secretary, to cooperate with the Indian Agent in regard to the purchase of this material.

I trust this will prove satisfactory, and you will find this the information you are seeking regarding the bill, presented from Fred C. Meyers and Company.

Yours very sincerely,

A.R. Lett.

PRINCIPAL— A. R. Lett.
Sir:-

I herewith beg to acknowledge departmental letter dated February 17th, in regard to Voucher No. 793R amounting to $55.37 in favor of Fred Meyer Company, covering cost of materials supplied to the St. George's Indian Residential School for manual training purposes, stating that the account was being paid but that you wished to point out that no authority was given for this expenditure and that I had been informed in circular letter dated November 14th, that authority should be obtained before incurring any expenditure.

With reference to this matter I beg to state that this expenditure was incurred last summer before the circular letter of November 14th, had been issued, and the reason, or one of the reasons, the account was not sent to Ottawa sooner, is that it was overlooked during the excitement following the fatal accidental self-shooting of Mr. H. Bachelor, the Manual Training Instructor.

I am enclosing a letter from the Rev. A. R. Lett, principal of the school, in explanation, which will speak for itself, and trust that this will prove satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, July 26, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing quotations which you received for supplying material required for use of the manual training classes at the St. George's Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of the purchase, from firms on the list to receive consideration, of the quantity of the various woods and hardware required, to an amount which must not exceed the sum of $110.

I enclose encumbrance certificate, authorizing an expenditure to the above amount. After the purchase has been made, please obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, covering the cost. This, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. You should state, on each copy of the voucher, that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E.R. No. 806.

I return herewith, for your information, the quotations which you forwarded. All quotations should accompany the vouchers which you submit for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. Strang, Esq.,

Sir:

I herewith beg to acknowledge receipt of departmental letter dated July 26, authorizing the sum of $110.00 for the purchase of hardware and hardwood for use at St. George's School in the Manual Training classes.

AS/MD
Ottawa, August 24, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, regarding the expenditure which was authorized in official letter of the 26th ultimo, for the purchase of hardware and hardwood to be used in the manual training classes at the St. George's Indian Residential School. In this connection it is noted that the sum authorized, viz.: $110, is not sufficient.

The total amount that can be allowed for the purchase of supplies for the manual training classes at this school during the coming academic year is $300. I enclose an encumbrance certificate authorizing a further expenditure of $190. This, with the authority already given you, will provide for an expenditure to the amount mentioned. You should therefore arrange for the purchase from a firm on the list to receive consideration. Please obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the materials purchased. This, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. You should state on each copy of the voucher that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E. R. Nos. 806 and 880.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE LYTTON INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL ON DECEMBER 18th AND 19th, 1933.

While Mr. White's work may be considered satisfactory and even good by the Principal, I am perfectly satisfied that far less time should be devoted to the drawing of detailed geometrical drawings of the articles to be constructed, and far more of the time spent in the actual handling of tools and the construction of articles which the boys may wish to make after they leave school. I have had so many talks with the Superintendent of Technical Instruction, Mr. John Kyle, over the best methods of instructing country boys, Indians or otherwise, that I know this is also his view. He and I agree that rough working sketches WITH DIMENSIONS are all that is required. The keeping of young boys at drawing boards during Manual Training periods leads me to conclude that the Instructor does not understand what is required. I have tried my best to point out to him that Indian boys do not require the same work as do boys in the Provincial High Schools. If the present Instructor is either unwilling or unable to change his methods by the time of my next inspection, I shall have to ask the Department to take the matter up with the Principal. If the manual Training given in the Residential Schools is not that which will fit the Indian boys for after school conditions, the sooner the Department saves its special grants for this purpose the better.
Ottawa, February 26, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

As soon as possible after March 31st next, you should forward to the Department a detailed report regarding the vocational training that is given at the St. George's Indian Residential School. This report should contain the following information:

(a) Instruction: Name and qualifications of instructor or instructors.

(b) Industries: Under this heading you should specify the industries taught, the number of pupils in each industry, number of hours weekly that each pupil is engaged, and list of work accomplished during the period April 1, 1933, to March 31, 1934.

(c) General Remarks: Under this heading you should state if the pupils are interested, and if you consider the results that are being obtained justify the expenditure that is being made.

If you feel that the value of the course could be improved, you should state in what manner you believe this could be done.

In addition to the above, you should let me know what is being done at your school to carry out the instructions contained in circular letter of March 15, 1931, a copy of which is enclosed.

The above projects include the necessary theory lessons, such as making of plans and elevations with instruments, followed by neat freehand sketches with all dimensions included; the comprehension of "Cutting Lists", bills of "material used"; lessons on care of tools, how to grind, whet, etc., is all included in the Manual Training instruction.
Section C. - General Interest.

Because of so much alfalfa grown the school keeps a small apiary whereby the boys receive instruction in bee husbandry. Bees do very well in the Dry Belt of British Columbia and could be made quite a payable investment.

The Indian craft of basketry which in this section of B. C. and especially among the Lower Thompson Tribes became advanced to a very high standard of craftsmanship and Indian art. It is now gradually becoming a thing of the past. I therefore feel that interest should again be aroused and provision made for an Indian woman to spend a short time each year in the school teaching the children in order that this craftsmanship might be perpetuated. The Indians could make quite a bit of this work, catering to tourist trade and the art therefore should not be allowed to become extinct. The Department would do well therefore to make some arrangement whereby this dying craft should again be revived.

Re circular letter of March 19, 1931.

In connection with your letter of March 19, 1931, I would respectfully call your attention to my answer to this circular, dated March 24, 1931, in which I stated that the milk production of the school herd was then all being used. This condition still exists because we have been obliged to butcher so many cows in connection with the abortion trouble in the barn. We therefore have not been able to instruct the girls in buttermaking as asked for.

We are endeavouring in every way to give the boys the general training called for and feel that if it is made possible for these boys to carry out in their after school life such training as is given, they would soon measure up to an equal standard with every independent citizen of our Dominion.

I trust you will find the above satisfactory and if there is any further information you desire I shall be pleased to forward the same.

Yours very obediently,

A. A. Lett,
Principal.
Boys:

There are 62 boys receiving vocational training.

Manual Training Department.

56 hours per week. 20 boys per month are rotated in this Department, repeating once every three months. List of work done enclosed on a separate sheet.

Farm.

56 hours per week. 26 boys are rotated each month. The farm is divided into the following departments: the dairy, 8 boys; gardening and fruit-growing, 4 boys; general farm work, 14 boys. The general farm work includes blacksmith shop, tractor and motor repairs, farm implements and general repairs, covering 640 hours during the year; Cleaning and treating seed grain, cutting and treating seed potatoes, 500 hours; Spraying and pruning, 448 hours.

The work in the dairy includes care and feeding of cows in general, making an individual study of productive, weighing of milk, value of feed and milk, advertising the ability of the cow to pay her way; care and sterilization of utensils; care of milk, making a study of methods which to keep down bacteria growth; sequence in breeding for production and testing; R.O.I. tests are made every six weeks by Dominion Inspectors.

Hogs - purebred Berkshires are grown, specially teaching the boys to make the best advantage of pasturage and general feeding to produce a choice hog in the shortest possible time.

Special seed plots are maintained in order that a high standard of seed should be produced, thereby assuring continuation of high production. Seed plots of beans, mangels, corn, potatoes. The school is endeavouring to teach the boys to grow alfalfa seed which in this district will be a very decided asset.

Engineering Department.

2 boys 56 hours a week. Care of boilers and generating of steam; care and running of motors; general plumbing repairs.

Section C. - General Interest.

The girls show a general interest in Domestic Science, sewing and in keeping themselves neat and tidy and in the general cleanliness of household work. It is generally believed by those who are in direct touch with them during their school life, they would, if given an opportunity, carry this out in their after school life. Their interest is especially keen in learning how to cook and bake.

We regret that more music cannot be given the girls as in the main they are musically inclined and it would afford great pleasures in after school life. The school would welcome assistance financially in this regard.

The boys show great aptitude and keenness in mechanical and carpentry work. We are fortunate at the present time to have an outstanding instructor in the Manual Training shop. The fact of his presence on the staff is due no doubt to general conditions existing in the industrial world, as a man of his calibre and ability cannot be picked up for the same amount offered by any other school. The course in the Manual Training shop is constructed so that it will meet with the general needs of the boy's after school life.

The above also applies in connection with the farm. The boys show general interest in the mechanical work and also in the scientific phase of farm industry on the whole but are not fond of the physical labour entailed in the production of hay and grain and other crops.

The tractor and motor repairs together with the blacksmith shop and repair of farm implements might be extended somewhat but do not feel that a special course in motor mechanics could be made available at the present time. Since these boys may be called to the care of themselves by agriculture, greater attention should be given to this department.
General Housework Department.

Every morning all girls, excepting those in the kitchen or laundry, are detailed for work throughout the school. This work, such as cleaning dormitories, making beds, working in the children's dining-room, tidying sitting-rooms, etc., is done in the hour between Chapel and school time. All the work is supervised by the girl's matron who judges and gives marks accordingly, thus encouraging the girls to do their very best.

On Saturday mornings the girls do housework from 8 a.m. till 12 a.m. and the school is scrubbed, swept, dusted, etc., from "top to bottom". Therefore all the girls get a thorough training in the art of housekeeping.

One girl each month is given special training in housekeeping working in the Residence under the supervision of the Head Matron. The Residence girl observes and learns the work of caring for a modern home. She does fine sewing, cooking for a family instead of large quantities such as done in the school kitchen, and all the work connected with housekeeping today.

Domestic Science - Special Classes.

Two afternoons a week the head matron has special classes for four of the older girls of the school. They are taught fancy cooking, making special desserts, bread and biscuit making. These girls have also made seat. The laundry matron who specializes in rugmaking, takes the Domestic Science girls in that work.

Practical Nursing.

All the rudimentary First Aid work is attended to by the girl's matron. The attending of sores, cuts, slivers, bruises, sprains, etc. is observed by the senior girls and when done by them is closely supervised by the girl's matron.

The girls have organized a Junior Red Cross Society and they are taught St. John's Ambulance course by the Junior Teacher. They learn bandaging, elementary anatomy course, first aid in fainting or drowning accidents.
Section A. - Instruction.

Domestic Science.

Miss G. Davies - 3rd class certificate for B.C. Teacher; managed and operated tearoom 10 years; Deputy-Provincial Girl Guide Commissioner for B.C.; experience in Strathcona Lodge, school for girls, Vancouver Island, B.C.

Miss J. Jobling - No certificate; a practical and plain seamstress; five years on staff as sewing-matron.

Miss H. Dalgleish - No qualifications; five years on staff as laundry-matron.

Miss M. Bird - Girl's Matron - Housework in general; 1st Class Certificate for B.C. Teacher.

Miss G. Fairbairn - Sport's Instructress - 2nd Class Certificate for B.C. Teacher; Strathcona Trust Certificate for Physical Training.

Mr. J. Piper - Farm Manager and general repair man - nine years in charge in general farming and experimental plots; five years handy man and machinist; making fourteen years experience on the Sutherland Estate, Brooks, Alta., which farm constitutes 7000 acres under irrigation.

Mr. R. Vaughan-Jones - Dairyman - Agricultural Certificate from Llysfasi Farm Institute, Ruthin, North Wales; demonstration lectures, practical work in dairying, feeding and milk testing, taken in a short course in Vancouver, B.C.

Mr. L. Stemp - Poultry, Orchard, Garden and Butchering - practical; short courses at University of B.C. on poultry raising and fruit farming.

Mr. S. F. Lepine - Engineer and Fireman - 4th Class B.C. Certificate.

Mr. J. S. White - Manual Training Instructor - B.C. Manual Training Instructor's Certificate; machinist and pattern maker.

Mr. A. C. Batchelor - Sport's Instructor - Dominion Cadet Trainer's Course.
Report re Vocational Training at St. George's School.

April 9, 1934.

Girls:

There are about 60 girls on the training list as the girls who are in Grade 1 do not work. These 60 girls are divided into two divisions, A and B. If the B-Division is in school, the A Division are busy in the different departments throughout the school, and so all the girls rotate. The list changes every month so by the end of the school year each girl has been in every department at least once.

Kitchen Department.

There are 5 girls in A Division and 5 girls in B Division detailed for the Kitchen each month. Each girl in each division is in the kitchen 7 hours in every 28 hours, making a total of 42 hours for each girl each week. 50 percent of this time is spent in actual instruction by the Kitchen Matron in cooking. The girls do all the cooking for both children and staff, which means they prepare 190 to 200 meals three times a day. The other 50 percent of the time is spent in preparing vegetables, washing-up, cleaning, etc. All this work is supervised and commented on by the Matron who advises and explains the best methods for doing such work.

Laundry Department.

There are 6 girls in A Division and 6 girls in B Division detailed for the Laundry each month. Each girl in each division is in the laundry 5½ hours each day except Saturday and Sunday, making a total of 26½ hours for each girl each week. The washing and ironing for the children and the staff, including clothes, bed linen, table linen, curtains, etc., is done, making over 1000 pieces going through the laundry each week.

1½ days each week is spent in rugmaking. These rug patterns are designed and drawn by the children. The rugs are hooked from old garments which are washed, dyed and made ready for use by the girls. Braided and knitted mats have also been made and these are used throughout the school in bedrooms and bathrooms.

Sewing Department.

There are 31 girls in the sewing-room each day, each girl putting in about 22 hours a week, as there is no work done on Saturday or Sunday. These are some of the things the girls have accomplished in this school term: 56 Sunday dresses, 185 everyday dresses, 72 nightgowns, 53 girl's shirts, 14 boy's shirts, 52 sheets, 16 pillow slips, 28 table napkins, 71 aprons, 12 mattress covers, 72 towels, etc. The girls patch, mend and make all the girls' clothes, make all the linen for the staff and all departments throughout the school such as doctor's towels, dishtowels, etc. They have made surplices and chapel collars for the choir. Formerly the girls knitted the boy's socks; now they re-boost them, but they confine their knitting to fancier articles, such as scarves, tams, sweaters. The girls are taught to embroider and to crochet.

The Matron asked me to recommend that two new Singer TAILOR machines be given to the school as they are so badly needed for this vocational training. I would recommend that consideration be given to this request, which I believe to be a reasonable one in view of the fact that so much construction work is done at St. George's School. Much money is saved by the making of the girls' dresses and other clothes in place of buying them, and the training given of necessity to the girls is of the greatest value.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I have been thinking over and have planned in my mind, with the cooperation of the Department, the building of a Log House such as we undertook to model in the Manual Training Shop last Spring and a picture of which you saw during my visit to the Dept. last May.

In connection with this, a number of our boy graduates have expressed the desire to return to the School for this training, and personally, I feel that it should be given them if at all possible.

This would necessitate, perhaps, an expenditure of $500 or $600, and also if the boys occupied space in the dormitory and received meals from the School, say, per capita earnings for this excess number.

I am anxious to try this project out, not only from the point of view of training for the boys and a model house for their homes on the reserves, but I also hope, when such building is finished, to house in it a teacher with two girls who would carry on general housekeeping, together with cottage handicrafts, which latter are now being taught in the School and which were very successfully exhibited at the Arts and Handicrafts Exhibition last Spring and also at the Canada Pacific this Autumn, and which handicrafts are very much in demand, especially our wool work. I foresee a nice revenue for girl graduates in their homes through this source of occupation.

I hope to begin this project, perhaps in the last week of this month, but not later than December 1st, because, before the frosts set in, I will be obliged to lay my foundations.
November 8, 1938.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

May I ask your co-operation, and perhaps any suggestions that you can make might be incorporated.

Yours very obediently,

[Signature]
Principal.

P.S. May I call your attention to the fact that we have not yet had an answer to our letter dated October 5th regarding pupils for whom we asked permission to give special training?
Ottawa, November 15, 1938.

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th instant, in which you discuss the desirability of proceeding with the construction of a log house at the St. George's Residential School.

I am personally very much interested in this proposal, and I consider your suggestion - that a couple of senior girls be placed in a house such as this, with a teacher in charge - particularly commendable. I am not at all sure, however, that we can seriously entertain the suggestion that pupils formerly enrolled at your school should be permitted to return to take up special vocational training. There are, as you know, a large number of districts in the province of British Columbia in which no educational facilities whatever have been provided by the Department. Just so long as such conditions exist anywhere in the Dominion, it is exceedingly difficult to justify expenditures on what one might term post graduate work. There is a possibility, of course, that night classes might be organized on an inexpensive basis for a number of grown-up boys and girls who live in comparatively close proximity to your school.

I was more than delighted to learn of the success of your handicraft exhibit at the Coast. I agree with you, that revenue can be obtained by girl graduates who are proficient in this work. A number of our Eastern Schools are experimenting with hand loom weaving, and I am sending forward a catalogue published by the Guild of All Arts, Scarborough, Ontario. Girls can operate these looms after a -

Dear Mr. Hoey:

We are forwarding to Miss Moody, who is in charge of the Handicrafts Department, one (1) rug each of tapestry, hooking, and weaving, and with them one (1) Cowichan sweater. I understood, from Dr. Moore when he visited the school a few days ago, that Miss Moody was turning quite a lot of this work over in your handicrafts department and while my main object is to let the Department see what the school is doing, it would be nice if Miss Moody could sell these things for us. The prices with designs are marked on the tickets.

My sewing matron was very loathe to forwarding the grey and black hooked mat as during our local exhibitions it has become dirtied, but I have persuaded her to send it forward to you and ask Miss Moody to have cleaned at your dry-cleaners. We shall be glad to take care of any expense incurred as there is no dry-cleaning place here to which we can send it. The sweater, hooked mat and woven mat are all products from the wool of our own sheep.

I trust this will give you some idea of what we are trying to do in handicrafts training.

Dear Mr. Lett:

On my return to Ottawa, Mr. Hoey transferred to me your letter of October 4 regarding the rugs and sweater. I think the rugs are very attractive, and am interested in knowing whether the small rug which is done in various colors has been made with vegetable-dyed yarn. The colors are lovely. I am having the black and grey hooked mat cleaned, and plan to send them to an exhibit of handicraft which is being put on by the Canadian Handicraft Guild in Montreal in November. We will send them as part of a display but will also quote the prices in the hope that they may find purchasers. It is rather difficult to sell individual articles as most of our sales are on a wholesale basis, but I feel sure that we will be able to sell at least one or two of the rugs and possibly the sweater, but I will write you further in this connection.

ONE of the most practical and "understanding" courses of training designed to meet the needs of Indian children when they return to their homes on the reserves is being put into effect in St. George's Indian Residential School at Lytton, British Columbia.

As a result of such training the Indians will be learning among other things, how comfortable and attractive houses may be built at small cost from materials to be found on, or near, every reserve. And the girls will be learning to use their fingers while they learn to make artistic curtains, towels, rugs, bedspreads and other articles suitable for commercial purposes.

The log cabin-building pictured on this page is an attractive four-room and bath structure, was built with a view to serving as a model for work. This cabin, built by two pupils and six "old boys" under the direction of an experienced carpenter, is to be used as a centre for training in home economics and handicrafts. The young pupils will be able to visualize the results of their efforts in a living room.

While under construction, the building was visited by the centre of interest for all the pupils, and many a boy on the sidelines absorbed the practical knowledge of building which threw a new and interesting light on his future, so well described in his manual training classes.

As the children—-as they watched the cabin walls go up log by log, they saw a vision of the day when they might build for their own, under improved living conditions on the reserve. And the turned to their weaving and stitching with their domestic duties with new zeal.

In the cabins they will learn to keep house on a family, rather than an institutional basis. They will see the curtains, the weaves hanging on "home" windows, their rugs laid on "home" floors. Ex-

Tending this idea further, Mr. Lett contemplates bringing an Indian mother and her baby to cabin in order to give the girls a course in child care.

THE HANDICRAFT training the girls receive, will serve a double purpose. They will not only be able to make rugs, blankets, towels and other articles for home use, stout Cowichan sweaters for their families, but they will literally at their finger tips, the means of developing a profitable business enterprise whereby in which the art of their own people will be prominently featured.

Ancient geometrical symbolic designs are being adapted to modern uses as can be seen on the rugs displayed in the picture. The Thompson Indians, artistic and in earlier days created many designs which they used to decorate their dwellings and clothing. Among the Thompson Indians, these designs appear especially frequently in their basketry. But it has been demonstrated at the school that these designs can be easily adapted to weaving, tapestry, knitting, and embroidery.

Mr. Lett is getting together as much of the old designs as he possibly can. In this case he has been able to get photographs of some of the designs which are present in themselves, very old design writing. These he hopes to incorporate in the designs of wood handicraft.

The girls are expected, displaying their skill in making rugs, a craft which lends itself wonderfully to Indian decoration. It is anticipated that great progress will be made in combining design in order to reproduce scenes of beauty and nature, such as a cloud effect in the border with an eagle in the clouds, symbolizing the spirit of mind.

Practical Courses for B.C. Indian Children

By Edna Kells

ONE of the most practical and "understanding" courses of training designed to meet the needs of Indian children when they return from their homes on the reserves, is being put into effect in St. George's Indian Residential School at Lytton, British Columbia.

As a result of this training, the Indian boys are learning among other things, how comfortable and attractive their log cabin built at small cost from material they have found on or near every reserve. And the girls are learning to use their fingers while they learn to make artistic clothes, towels, rugs, bedspreads for home equipment and for commercial purposes.

The log cabin, which is pictured on this page, an attractive living room and bath structure, was built with the help of the pupils who did the work. This cabin, built by two pupils and six "old boys" under the direction of an experienced carpenter, is to be used as a centre for training the pupils in the art of handicraft. Thus the young pupils will be able to visualize the results of their efforts in a practical rather than an institutional setting.

Back of all this lies a story. The Rev. Mr. Lett, principal of the school, is blessed with vision and an understanding of the executive abilities.

Well, we can understand the reluctance of many of the older girl students to return to their homes on the reserves at the end of their ten year training in the spacious, well-developed school. There they would have to combat the old and manner of living not far removed from the primitive. There was little hope of raising the standard of living, the idea so carefully awakened in them, yet doubt, if not actually killed, in the struggle.

For the more intelligent pupils, the happiness of the latter years of their school life was overshadowed by dread of what was to come after.

This dread is being dispelled by Mr. Lett who, through his carefully thought out plan is giving the pupils training which will be of practical assistance to them in solving their home problems, as well as appealing to their imagination and developing their creative ability.

Manual training and handicraft have long been an important part of the curriculum of Canada's Indian residential schools. But Mr. Lett has not been content with the routine training. It is not enough, he says, that the pupils should be taught to do this and that; the girls taught to do housework, to sew, to weave and knit. They must also be taught how to actually live and how to make good use of the knowledge they acquire, to their benefit on the reserves, and through this to improve the lives of their own people who have had fewer advantages, as well as enjoy better living conditions and a fuller life all around.

Boys Build Cabin

With this in view the cabin, which is 30 by 32 feet, was built under the direction of a competent carpenter, Philip McLean. As the young builders worked, they acquired a practical knowledge of woodwork as well as in the work of their hands. As much of the material as possible was collected from the surrounding country, so they also learned how to find and make use of that which lay at hand instead of merely dreaming of homes which they could not afford to build, or making shift for themselves when they might have good homes.

The substantial cement foundation was laid by the pupils with much of the old design work as possible. In some cases he has even been able to get reproductions of rock paintings and carvings which are used as designs for rug design writing. These he hopes to reproduce in the development of tool handling.

The girls are depicted, displaying their skill in rug craft which lends itself wonderfully to Indian design. In rug work an effort is made among the pupils to reproduce some of the more beautiful ideas, such as a bird, a fish, a bear, a wolf, with an eagle in the centre. This in reality is a form of art, the best symbolizing the development of mind as well as body.

Here the object is two-fold—to utilize the imagination in the child, to demand a product which will create a liking for the finer things.

Indians are primarily great naturalists and if this appreciation of the natural world is to be developed, it will be a valuable addition to their handicraft skills.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

In October, 1939, we sent to the Handicraft Section some articles made by the children. I understand that most of these have now been sold, but that a tapestry rug is still on hand, and I have been wondering whether you would accept this rug as a souvenir of the work being done in St. George's School by the Handicraft class. It will give our pupils much pleasure to know that this rug has been accepted by you, and they will be encouraged by your interest.

Yours very sincerely,

Principal.
Ottawa, February 8, 1941.

Dear Mr. Lett:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23th ultimo, in which you intimate that the pupils of your school are anxious to present me with the Tapestry Rug sent forward a few months ago with a number of other handicraft products to the Welfare Section of this Branch.

I must express regret that we have been unable, so far, to secure a market for this particular rug. In view of this fact, I shall be glad to adopt the suggestion contained in your communication. Please accept and convey to the pupils my most sincere thanks for their generosity.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

In official letter of October 29, 1940, you were authorized to expend approximately $35.40 in the purchase of hardware for the vocational training class at the St. George's Residential School.

On December 16 Indian Agent Strang forwarded his voucher No. 610z for $35.49 in favour of McLennan, McFeely & Prior. On reviewing invoice No. 83745 attached to the voucher it was found that McLennan, McFeely & Prior requested a total payment of $36.59. Included in this amount was an item of $1.10 for freight and when the invoice reached here, attached to Mr. Strang's voucher, the item of $1.10 had been struck out and the total of the account shown as $35.49. Indian Education

By K.M.H.

There is a residential school for Indian boys and girls near Lytton, British Columbia, which according to a writer in "Country Life," British Columbia, "appears to be feeling its way towards education for the first Canadians which will be of real value to the Indians of their country. Canada has, from its very beginning, been conscious of its responsibility for the Indian race and the past of its history has numerous examples of well meant attempts to discharge this obligation. However, except in a few instances, the best effort and good will expended on the schools for Indian girls and boys might better have been poured down the drain. Some of these persons unavoidable came to the meeting of one type of civilization with another. Some of it is due to the singular inability of the Indians by their directors in this education, then blindness to the conditions of life which would surround their graduates.

It is from the beautiful valleys of the Fraser and the Thompsons that the children come to this Lytton school where Rev. A. R. Lett is principal. There are acres of land, most of which, by the way, must be irrigated. This point had been overlooked in 1901 when the school was instituted, it being then the idea that the graduates would settle near it. However, 160 acres are now cultivated and the writer, Mr. Stewart, has told me that of the crops of alfalfa, oats and vegetables, some of them harvested three times a year. There are orchards also.

He has to recount much also of the cattle herd and the sheep flock, of the pigs and the hens, and the market garden has not yet sold off the place of the products of these products. He also has to tell of the providing of the school with gallons of fresh milk and with every variety of the food grown there.

Some of this sort of thing has been done at other Indian schools, but unless the children get this growing "virus" into their own veins and do not go through the same experiments which they don't get them anywhere. Principal Lett is evidently aware of this and is attempting to meet it.

The boys of the school, for instance, have built a log cabin and the girls have helped to furnish it. Various buildings are being carried out there under conditions which could, within possibility, obtain in homes which the graduates could and may set up. Just how much of this hard work preserves the Indians' own fine traditions in this field we do not know, nor do we know in the preserving of fruits and vegetables how much cognizance is taken of the conditions under which these projects must be carried out in the Indian home—where there isn't apt to be electricity, and whether any effort is made to teach the Indians our way of preserving these things by the drying method.

There is another point also where the writer has not been explicit. He tells of the academic study and the physical training, including dancing. However fine the traditions of England may be, there need not be anything but a mild feeling of mildness settling upon us when a group has obliged with a morris dance. The Indians have dances of their own which certainly do not lack in life and mettle. How about some of these in the physical training? They are the Indians' own assets.

Principal Lett does have thought all of these things. The article in question leaves one with definite hopes that he has.

There is another hope on the horizon today in Indian education. It is the fact that Mr. R. A. Hoey, to whom this Province is indebted for his work here as Inspector of Schools, is now Superintendent of Welfare and Training, Indian Affairs branch, Ottawa.

Ottawa, October 24, 1941.

Dear Major MacKay:

Mr. H.G. Charlton, in his special audit report on the St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C., dated October 9, 1941, submits for departmental consideration a number of recommendations, the adoption of which would in his judgment contribute substantially to the efficient management and operation of the school.

These recommendations will be sent forward to you in due course, but at the moment I am particularly interested in Recommendation 17, which reads as follows:

"The Manual Training section should list the current stock of saleable articles—priced as agreed upon. A list of additions to stock should be furnished monthly. All sales, whether for cash or on consignment, should be recorded by the counter sales book. These should be in triplicate—one with the goods, one with the office, and one with Mr. McLean. Returns to stock should be recorded in the same manner and plainly marked 'RETURNS'. All transactions should go through the school books and there should be no separate ventures with separate bank accounts."

This is the first intimation the Department has had that handicraft or manual training products produced at our schools were offered for sale through the ordinary commercial channels, and I find the news somewhat disturbing. In the province of Manitoba—and I feel this is also true of the other provinces—the products made at technical schools are not offered for sale. A few years ago the Labour representatives on the Winnipeg School Board and in the Manitoba Legislature took a strong stand on this question, and it was agreed then that no products made in a school established for educational purposes and maintained by public funds should be disposed of through the ordinary channels of trade, in competition with the regular supplies produced by factories. It is now customary, I understand, to have the pupils to a very large extent decide on their own projects. When a pupil decides to build a table or a chair, the material necessary is purchased by the school and the task is undertaken by the pupil under the direction of an instructor. When the article is completed it becomes the property of the boy who has made it; after he returns to the school the actual cost of the material. Public exhibitions at a great many of these schools are held annually, but no goods are offered for sale. On the other hand, at a number of subnormal institutions throughout the

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.
Dominion, where vocational therapy is encouraged, annual exhibitions or bazaars are held. Inasmuch as the pupils at such institutions have been committed for long periods, the articles produced are usually sold to visitors and the proceeds become part of the regular school funds.

I am anxious that you with your officials should work out a uniform policy that will meet conditions in B.C. I am anxious that nothing should be done to discourage in any way or in any sense vocational instruction or manual arts at our residential schools, and I am also anxious that these goods should not, except in very exceptional cases, be offered for sale. I am afraid that if such goods are offered for sale a number of our residential school principals will find it difficult to resist the temptation to produce for profit and thus the pedagogical features of manual training would be overlooked or relegated to a subordinate position. Where a boat, or boats, have been built at a school, I do not suppose there would be any serious objection to the disposal of a boat to a group of pupils, who might use it for fishing after their graduation. Mr. Doucet, with whom I have discussed this matter very fully, is of the opinion that the repair of school buildings, the production of furniture necessary at the school, windows, frames, tables, etc., should occupy a great deal of their time. He is also of the opinion that the construction of model Indian homes, where a residential school is close to a reserve, might be encouraged, or the construction of fabricated homes where a school is not near a reserve.

There is no particular urgency about this matter, but it is one that should be reviewed and a definite policy worked out, when you and your officials have the time necessary to undertake such a task.

Yours very truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Prince Rupert, B.C., June 10, 1942.

The Director:

On Saturday May 30th, Dr. Barley and I left Vancouver and visited...........

On June 2nd, we drove to Lytton and while there visited St George's school, St Bartholomew's Hospital and Dr. Ellis, with Agent Strang.

The agent reports an improvement in the school since Mr. Hives has taken charge. At the time of our visit the children were recovering from an epidemic of mumps. The Infirmary appeared neat and clean, with a capacity of twelve beds and a nurse in charge. The drugs were in good order.

Mr. Hives requested the children be inoculated for Scarlet Fever as there is some in the district. In talking this over with Dr. Ellis he preferred they be toxoided against Diphtheria, and stated that he wanted extra pay for this work. Dr. Ellis states he should be paid extra for vaccinations as well. It is pointed out that preventative medicine is a big part of practice now and this type of work should be done by the part-time Medical Officer, under the salary arrangement.

The school here is stressing manual training and have a well equipped work room and are showing some excellent work done by the children.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.
Asst. Supt. Medical Services.

Dear Sir:

While School Inspector McArthur was here a few weeks ago, he recommended that we secure small kindergarten tables for one of the classrooms. I would like to get these made in the Manual Shop if we can get the lumber. I have recently been able to locate some suitable lumber from a local merchant, and can buy this at a fair price.

The School Inspector also asked if we could make similar tables for the Indian School at Boothroyd. We would do this along with our own tables.

The cost of the lumber is $37.00. Will you kindly ask the Department if they would allow me to purchase this lumber to be used as part of the Manual training project.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.
LYTTON, B.C. June 5, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, VANCOUVER, B.C.

I enclose herewith an application from the Principal of the St. George's Indian Residential School, asking permission to purchase approximately 300 f.b.m. clear cedar for the manual training shop, at a cost of $37.00. This price compares very favourably with the amount paid for clear cedar for coffins for this Agency. I would respectfully recommend that the Principal's request receive your favourable consideration.

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

D.M. MacKay,

I have received a request from the Reverend Principal Hives of St. George's Indian Residential School that he be allowed to continue the use of the services of the Manual Training Instructor during the months of July and August in order that he may make necessary repairs to the institution during that period.
