Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, it has been decided to forward Mr. Hives a cheque for $250.00 from the New England Company funds. This will permit him to pay the manual training instructor for the months of July and August and also purchase paint at a cost of $150.00. We feel that this is a better way to handle the request than to continue the salary of the manual training instructor from the B.C. Special appropriation.

While the cheque is being sent to Mr. Hives, we are not writing to him, as I thought that possibly you could secure the paint in Vancouver for him at a more reasonable cost than he would pay in Lytton.

Philip Phelan,

I have received a request from the Reverend C. F. Hives, Principal of St. George's Indian Residential School that he be allowed to continue the use of the services of the Manual Training Instructor during the months of July and August in order that he may make necessary repairs to the institution during that period. Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O.

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant it has been decided to forward Mr. Hives a cheque for $250 from New England Company funds. This will permit him to pay the manual training instructor for the months of July and August and also purchase paint and other materials to make minor repairs. As stated to you last year, we feel that this is a better way to handle the request than to continue the salary of the manual training instructor from the B.C. Special Appropriation.

We are following the same procedure as last year with regard to the cheque; namely, we are sending this direct to Mr. Hives, but we are not writing to him as I thought it likely that you would be purchasing the paint and materials in Vancouver.

R.A. Hoey,

Nov. 7, 1945

Dear Sir:

With reference to my letter of August 13th requesting certain power tools for our Manual shop; which request, I regret to say, was refused by the Department, I am writing to ask if you will kindly forward to the Department an urgent request that they would reconsider their decision regarding the power tools. I assure you that they would be of great value in training the boys. They would be a great attraction to the boys. And they would be a great asset in the matter of making useful articles and doing work in connection with our school.

The Kamloops school has much more in their workshop than I have asked for. I am informed that they are a great success in helping toward training the boys. The tools would be used only under the control and supervision of the Manual Instructor. The boys are never allowed in the shop excepting under supervision.

All technical schools have power tools. I don't see why we should always be behind white schools in the matter of equipment etc. Almost any modern Manual Instructor looks upon the power tools as standard equipment.

I would be very much obliged if you would please present the request again to the Department.

Yours faithfully,

Principal.

Mr A. Strang,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

A. Strang,

Dear Colonel Neary:

I was glad to get your letter telling me that hopes of obtaining lower tools is becoming more of a reality. You were asking if I had yet been able to buy a car. I have not, but the money is safe, for I have put it in a Special account, making note of it in my Monthly Financial Statement.

This week, I am hoping to make a trip to Chilliwack to interview the Public School Inspector, in order to find out what facilities exist in that district in the matter of vocation schools; and if the cream of our schools could be allowed to attend them. I am convinced that something of that nature has to be done for our graduate pupils. At the present time the education we give them does not get them anywhere. In fact, I think sometimes, that it is almost more of a menace to their progress; for we take them so far, and tell them all kinds of glowing accounts of the wonderful world that is awaiting them; but when they leave us to go to the "wonderful" world, they are absolutely lost. They know not the eyes of the people outside our care and influence. I am convinced, in my own mind, that our advanced pupils should mingle in the classrooms and vocational shops with other children of the country. I have seen this method working with great success time and time again when I was at Shingwauk. And I am sure you will find that ninety per cent of those pupils who attended Technical High School, during the twelve years I was at Sault Ste. Marie, are living honorable and useful lives, since they have gone out into the world. I found always that our pupils were most popular amongst the pupils of the school. Young people are not so choosy in the matter of race, color or creed as older people.

I will write you again after my trip to Chilliwack, and, if possible, put forth another
of my wild, and perhaps daring recommendations.

We had a very delightful visit from Mr. Tom Reid, M.P. Before he left, he very graciously told me that I now have a "friend in court." He seemed to be quite thrilled with what he saw here. So perhaps his visit will bear fruit in due season.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

I went down and saw Mr. Jones, the Director of Technical Education, this morning and received the information you requested. He says that they have less trouble with accidents with band saws than with circular saws and that it is even less likely that an accident should occur with a planer and jointer. With a jointer the most serious thing that is likely to happen is that 1/8 of an inch of the finger might be taken off which would, of course, only involve the fleshy part. However, this would only happen in the case of gross carelessness. Incidentally you had "jointer" in your letter but this was an error in the typing I believe. Regarding the safety precautions, Mr. Jones said that he tried to insist that pupils used power operated machinery only when in view of the instructor. In addition he said that they secured a considerable amount of information from the Department of Labour (Provincial) which publishes a number of pamphlets on the use of equipment such as is used in the schools. I may say that I also phoned my brother Jack who is a shops Foreman at the Vancouver Island Coach Lines where they have and use considerably a band saw in their body repair work. He said that the band saw is far more generally useful than a circular saw and is probably less dangerous. In addition it is coming into much more general use now, particularly since the war. He also thought that the band saw was less dangerous than the circular saw. The wheels over which the saw runs should be guarded as should the run where the teeth are going up leaving only the opening where the sawing actually takes place exposed.

I secured from Mr. Jones sheets of the equipment required for different types of technical work, woodwork, metalwork, and electricity, for Junior and Senior High School. He said that the lists were not complete in that the Senior High woodwork was missing. However I notice that there is a list clipped to the end of the Junior High sheets which seems to cover the Senior High so I think that everything is there. He promised to send me down a copy when he got one so unless there is no difference I shall send it along when I get it.

Provision of power tools for the Schools of British Columbia

You have recently requested that we clarify the whole situation insofar as the provision of power tools to Residential Schools of British Columbia is concerned. Therefore, in answer, we would like to point out the following general policy which will be followed by the Department in this regard:

1. MANUAL TRAINING TEACHERS

The Department will provide power tools for manual training shops where the teacher is fully qualified and holds the proper teaching certificates granted by the Department of Education of the Province of British Columbia. In all other cases, each individual instructor's qualifications will be carefully considered before approving expenditures for power equipment.

The grants to be made by the Department for the purchase of power tools will be based upon the attendance at the residential school concerned.

2. USE OF POWER TOOLS BY STUDENTS

It is understood that in the manual training shops of the junior and senior high schools of the Province of British Columbia, pupils use power operated machinery

....... only when in
only when in view of the instructor. It is most essential that a similar precaution be employed in our schools, especially in view of the fact that our manual training begins often at an earlier age for Indian boys than for boys in the provincial schools.

3. **INSPECTION OF SAFETY DEVICES**

It is understood that the Workmen's Compensation Board of the Province of British Columbia will send one of their Inspectors to check the installation of these power tools and will be glad to give whatever advice is required in their operation. In all instances where residential schools have such equipment or are installing such equipment, this service of the Workmen's Compensation Board should be used.

4. **SAFETY LITERATURE FROM THE WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION BOARD**

It is most essential that all such literature receives the fullest distribution throughout the manual training shops of our schools using power tools. These posters must be displayed in our manual training shops and the Inspector of Schools will ensure that this is done. Indian agents should also check on this practice in their visits to our schools.

5. **SAFETY PRECAUTIONS REGARDING THE USE OF POWER TOOLS.**

(a) **Saws:** It is now generally agreed by the various Directors of Technical Education for the Provincial Departments of Education that there are fewer accidents when power saws are used than with circular saws. In industry the band saw is more generally useful than a circular saw and is also less dangerous.

The band saw should at all times have a guard over it, leaving only the opening exposed where the actual sawing takes place. Boys should not stand at the side of a band saw.
5. (b) Planers: It is unlikely that an accident should occur when pupils are using this tool. However, care should be taken that the feed is not too heavy and that no one stands in front of the plane.

(c) Jointers: The most serious thing that is likely to happen in an accident using this tool is that 1/8" of the finger might be taken off, which would of course involve only the fleshy part. However, this would only happen in the case of gross carelessness.

The jointer should have a telescopic rear-guard as well as a standard swing-guard in the front so that at no time any portion of the knife is open other than that over which work is passing. When using short material, pupils should always use a push stick.

6. CONCLUSION

It is felt that if the Principals of Residential Schools and Indian Agents are all made aware of the above precautions, very few accidents should occur in our manual training shops. It is realized that this training in operating such machinery will be most valuable to our Indian students and will enable them to obtain better positions in the mills and factories of your province.

Director.

Extract from Inspector Davey's report on the St. George's Residential School on February 4, 1948. Original on file # 165-0-6.

The work in this Department was rather disappointing. The Instructor is a good craftsman and had had experience in instructing in the army; but most of the work of the pupils appears to have been along the lines of work with power tools or in doing maintenance work about the school. Some of this has a very definite educational value, but should not exclude instruction which aims at teaching certain fundamental operations and the care and use of basic tools. To ensure that these have not been omitted the Instructor should follow a well defined programme. The writer has tried to be of assistance in this respect by requesting the instructor to requisition for the Manual First Year Woodwork, which has been prepared by the Training Branch, and by giving him a list of reference books and manuals which he is to requisition. The Principal will see that the course is followed.

MEMORANDUM

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.

From: The District School Inspector.

Re: Manual Training Supplies
St. George's Residential School

The attached requisition from the above-mentioned school appears to be too large in some items, particularly lumber. It would seem that the Reverend Principal intended to use some of this for maintenance or new construction.

I have placed a red cross against those items which I think should be deleted and have shown the quantities I think should be supplied where the order appears to be excessive.

R.F. Davey,
Dist. School Inspector.
April 9, 1948.

Air Mail

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I am enclosing herewith a requisition in quadruplicate covering the supply of manual training tools and materials for the St. George's Indian Residential School, together with a memorandum dated April 2nd from District School Inspector Davey in this connection.

The estimated cost of the tools, nails, screws etc. recommended by Mr. Davey is approximately $250.00 and the cost of the lumber, the supply of which he recommends, is approximately $300.00. I would recommend that the Department authorize the purchase of tools and materials to these amounts.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
April 20, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 9th instant, file 7-11-6 (165), the Department approves the purchase of tools, nails, screws, at a cost of approximately $250.00 and also the purchase of lumber at a cost of approximately $300.00 for the manual training class at the St. George's Indian Residential School.

When forwarding accounts you should mark on them "Pay from B.C. Special".

The above authority is given on the understanding that any items which Inspector Davey considers are not required should be deleted and where the order appears to be excessive, the quantities requested should be reduced.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Mackenzie:

In connection with the troubles we have been having with our dairy herd, I might say that I have been in touch with Mr. F. Moore, Superintendent of the Provincial Farm at Essendale, with a view of trying to overcome the situation existing in the herd through Abortion, and I would ask to be allowed to have Dr. Jagger take another blood test at his next visit during this month so that we could, in co-operation with Mr. Moore, who has kindly offered to take our Positives, using them for beef in the Institution, and for them give us some of his young stock, which this Autumn he is obliged to dispose of. Personally, I think this is a very, very good offer, and the school should not hesitate to avail themselves of this opportunity.

It is true, we shall not be able to do away entirely with at least two of our high productive cows, one of whom is now giving 86 lbs. milk per diem, on three times a day milking. We can, however, provide isolation for two or three of these cows, and in that way, keep them for the purpose, perhaps, of getting a few heifer calves as well as to keep up our milk supply.

I have written Dr. Jagger to be prepared to make a blood test, as I have no hesitancy in feeling that you will agree with this proposition, as it will not cost the Department anything over the blood test, which is 25¢ per cow tested, and it will put us in a position wherein we shall not need the services of Dr. Jagger, I hope, more than once a quarter, excepting in extreme cases.

Yours very faithfully,

A. R. Lett.
Principal.

Dear Sir:

Just a report on the recent blood test taken to determine the percentage of cases affected with the Bacillis Abortus. I make the following statement.

Out of thirty one tested there are two positives, three suspicious, these, together with five positives not tested, make a total of seven positives and three suspicious in the barn. I have had a long conversation with Dr. Jagger on the condition of the barn at present, and it is his opinion that we ought not to bring in any more cattle, but continue with our cleaning up system, for the test shows the disease has not been on the increase, but rather decreasing as the time goes by.

Twice in succession our Senior Sire has been a suspicious character and Dr. Jagger feels that this bull should be immediately taken out and because of this, I have been in touch with Mr. P. Moore of the Colony Farm, who has been, and is now catering to our breeding necessities, and he has offered to let me have a young bull who will follow up our breeding, and for whom he asks a sum of $50.00, also adding that he wishes the bull to be held by the school and Colony Farm as joint ownership so that if necessary the bull will be available for the show ring, as this year, this young individual travelled with his stock to exhibitions in British Columbia. I will be grateful, therefore, if the Department could see fit to make payment for this bull, as this is an unforeseen necessity in connection with the dairy.
Mr. A. F. McKenzie-

We are at the present time, shipping alfalfa hay to Colony Farm, and could take care of the bull out of the money we shall receive, but in order that we should not be obliged to make this payment, we would appreciate the Department returning the money to us if at all convenient and being available.

Yours very obediently,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, regarding the recent tests carried out to determine the cases affected with Bacillus Abortus among the dairy herd at the St. George's Indian Residential School and requesting that a grant of $50.00 be allowed for the purchase of a bull, to be under the joint ownership of the school and the colony farm.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your request for a report on health conditions in the dairy herd at St. George's School, I would say that Bang's Disease is the only infectious condition you have to contend with at the present time.

In a number of dairy herds we are handling Bang's Disease by blood tests every ninety days, segregation of the positives in separate pastures and on opposite ends or sides of the dairy barn.

The heifer calves are kept away from the older animals until they are ready to be placed in the milking herd.

While this method of handling is not absolute isolation yet it offers an economical way of handling this disease. True one may have occasional breaks under this system but the blood tests will detect these and it gives you reasonable control instead of working in the dark.

It also gives you a chance to raise a herd of clean heifers from your heavy producing cows.

In regard to the milk from the positive cows being dangerous and liable to produce undulant fever in the human, I do not think you need have any worry in that regard.

The people of the world have been using milk from cows affected with Bang's Disease for ages. The number of known cases are few in comparison with population and not many of these can be traced directly to milk consumption.

Undulant fever is more of an occupational disease, affecting those coming in actual contact with the diseased animals and most of these cases seem to be traceable to infection from hogs or pork. The porcine strain of organism seems to be much more virulent for the human than does the bovine organism.

In any event the milk can always be made safe by pasteurization.

The question of sterility in dairy herds is one that gives a great deal of trouble and loss of dairy time.
Sterility was formerly looked upon as a part of Bang's Disease but since we started to use the blood test for Bang's Disease we find that there is just about as much sterility in the negative animals as there is in the positives.

I have been in close touch with the question of sterility for the past fourteen years and find that over ninety percent of the cases are due to various ovarian conditions. These ovarian troubles are a separate condition having nothing to do with Bang's Disease.

In order to keep a dairy herd in good production it is necessary to have the herd checked up for ovary troubles. This examination gives you the following information.

1st: Each animal is examined for pregnancy seven to eight weeks after breeding. If she is not pregnant it gives information on the condition of the genital organs.

2nd: It reveals the actual conditions of those animals giving trouble as a result of ovarian diseases and about eighty percent of these can be corrected.

3rd: It saves a large loss of dairy time by picking out and treating those cows and heifers that are served and stand for several months without showing signs of estrus although they are not pregnant.

In other words it is good herd bookkeeping and lets you know what each animal is doing instead of working in the dark.

You have been very fortunate in not having much udder trouble in your herd.

The above outline coupled with the recent report on the herd blood test, I believe, completely covers the situation at the present time.

Yours truly,

T.H. Jagger

All the symptoms I could find were stiffness in the legs, and pain if almost any part of the body was touched. The hog pen is fairly clean, the pens have concrete floors, with not enough bedding in my opinion. I found no evidence or symptoms of hog cholera, and evidently from the non-success of the agression, the trouble is not hemorrhagic septicaemia, and as the sickness is confined to the small hogs I came to the conclusion that the trouble was of a dietary nature, caused by some irritant in the garbage, but not violent enough to affect the mature hogs. Dear Sir:

Your letter of January 31, together with copy of one from Dr. Jagger, has been referred to us by Dr. Archibald.

In this connection, I would say that we have had wonderful results in our herds from the application of the blood test for the eradication of contagious abortion. Starting in 1928 we put all of our herds on this test and immediately there were only a few reactors; we disposed of them at once. In three or four years we segregated reacting animals and saved their calves from these to put into the negative herd. We kept this up for three or four years in some cases until the herds were properly built up again but in 1933 we disposed of the last of our reacting animals and now have abortion-free herds on all of our farms.

Much of the credit for this work must be given to the Health of Animals Branch of the Department of Agriculture with which branch we had the closest cooperation in this work. They have recently issued a publication on abortion in cattle covering this system of eradication of disease and offering a service similar to that which they have given us to the rank and file of breeders in the country, provided they are prepared to carry out certain conditions and regulations. I am asking the Animal Diseases Research Institute, Health of Animals Branch to forward you a copy of this bulletin and I think you will find many of your questions answered therein and I would suggest that you take advantage of their offer and put your herd under their supervision.

As you will note, the blood samples will be taken by your local practicing veterinarian and in your case they would be forwarded to Dr. Bruce at the Animal Pathological Laboratory, Saanichon, B.C., for examination and report.

Dear Sir:

A letter has just been received from Rev. Mr. Hives, Principal of the St. George's Residential School, which reads, in part, as follows:

"The matter of obtaining meat is a very serious situation, and yet it should not be, and would not be if I had a thousand dollars to buy twenty head of cattle. Instead of which, I have to sit by and see the Jew come in and buy them from the Indians. If there is a thousand dollars in the coffers of New England Company, I do not know of any better way it could be spent than by buying cattle. We have the feed to fatten them, and there is no more profitable way of disposing of cattle feed than by feeding it. If therefore you can possibly send us a thousand dollars from New England Company fund, will you please write me by air mail, so that if possible I may get ahead of the Jew and safeguard our meat supply for the winter."

It is rather difficult for us to decide if it is either advisable or necessary to make the expenditure requested by the Principal. The last information that we have regarding the livestock at the St. George's School indicated that there should be sufficient to meet the needs. I should appreciate very much having your comments on the Principal's request.

Yours truly,

I have for acknowledgement letter No. 315-7-920 relative to my letter to Mr. Hoey, in which I asked for a special grant with which to buy beef cattle. Below is a list of the number of cattle attached to St. George's School.

You may see what our situation is, and how impossible it is to supply ourselves with beef from our own herd. I do not know when the last report went in to the Department regarding our cattle, but we have had to buy beef most of the year, and we shall have to continue doing so for sometime. It is extremely difficult purchasing beef cattle, unless one has the ready cash with which to pay for them. Had we the cash now, I might be able to buy some, but buyers, (mostly Jews) come around and offer cash to the Indians, and they get the cattle. The result is, we have to buy our beef from the retailer, and pay high prices. This school cannot afford to do that. During the past year we have met our current expenses with the bare per capita grant. Whatever extra grant we have had from the New England Company special grant has been used to meet extraordinary expenses in the matter of replacements and repairs. In other schools such expenses are met from special grants from the Department.

In a pamphlet just received from M.S.C.C., there is an item, herewith attached, which clearly states that the per capita grant has to be supplemented by another $30.00 per capita, which they depend upon receiving from the Church people, as well as clothing and footwear for all girls in their schools and boys up to eleven years' age.

We have met our current expenses with the per capita grant, but I assure you, sir, we have had to be on the verge of stinginess, and there has been little chance to waste anything.

I do hope we shall be able to receive the special New England Company grants, which the school is really in need of.

I expect to be in Vancouver next Thursday, and would like to call on you at that time.

Yours faithfully,

Sir,

Will you allow me to bring the following matter to your kind attention?

When I came to this school in November 1893 I started a band with the boys of the school, or rather I tried to start one, but saw myself forced to give it up, for the following reason:

To make a band, one must of course have instruments to play on. Now, I found here some instruments, but not enough to make a band. There was a band at this school at one time, before the present principal, Rev. A. Lett, took charge, but some of the instruments must have been lost, as at present there are not instruments enough to make a band. I approached Rev. Lett, with a view of having some more instruments bought, but he told me that this was an impossibility for him, as the capital grant is barely sufficient to purchase the necessaries of food, clothing, etc., for the children, without allowing for any luxuries. So, there is no hope to have the necessary instruments paid for out of the school funds. Before I came here I occupied a position similar to the one I occupy here at the Fraser Lake Industrial School. There I had a very successful band. The instruments were nearly all second-hand ones, and I remember the prices paid for them.

To make this band a success, and even a possibility, I would need three more instruments, and the prices would not be more, for the three of them, than from $25.00 to $75.00.

Would it be asking too much to ask you that you take this matter up with the Department, and present the situation, and ask for the granting of the sum mentioned above, in order to enable me to go ahead with the band? You will agree with me that it is a very good thing for the school in general, and for the boys in particular, to have a band. I have seen the good effects of a band in several schools, both white and Indian, and I am sure that it would be a boon for this Institution.

I trust you will see fit to endorse this request.

Yours very sincerely,

1. GENERAL.

There are three Cadet Corps organized in connection with Indian Residential Schools in Military District, No.11, namely:

No. 1077, St. George's (Lytton) Cadet Corps.
No. 1102, Alert Bay Cadet Corps.
No. 1295, Coqualeetza (Sardis) Cadet Corps.

A brief summary of the training carried out at each school is given hereunder.

2. ST. GEORGE'S (LYTTON) C.C.

St. George's Cadet Corps, organized February, 1923, is situated at the Residential School some three miles from Lytton, in the interior of British Columbia. The training is supervised by the Principal of the School, the Rev. A. Lett, and assisted by one of the members of the Staff. During the School year 1929-30, 65 boys of Cadet age were enrolled and participated in the training. The boys are keenly interested in the work. At the annual inspection the results showed sound training. The Physical Training and Games, Corps discipline, and signalling were very good. First Aid was above the average, and the Inspecting Officer presented 21 St. John Ambulance Certificates to the Cadets. This percentage, about 50%, or certificates for this branch of the work is considered very high.

The boys were instructed in the proper use of .22" B.S.A.Rifles and enter into indoor rifle matches with enthusiasm.

The Principal of the School is keen on the training as a whole, not only from the point of view of disciplinary effects, but in the production of boy leaders which is the result of the training.

The Corps has shown marked improvement at each annual inspection.

3. ALERT BAY C.C.

Alert Bay Corps, organized in November, 1923, is situated near the northern end of Vancouver Island, at St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C. The training is supervised by the Principal of the School, Mr. F. Earl Anfield, and instructed by Lt.Commander J.I.Jordan, R.N. (ret.); both of these gentlemen are qualified in Physical Training and as Cadet Instructors. During the School year 1929-30, 55 boys of Cadet age were enrolled and trained.

The Corps is trained along very sound lines, boys keenly interested. A trophy awarded for competition among Indian School Cadet Corps by the Imperial Daughters of the Empire was won four consecutive years by the Alert Bay Corps and is retained by them. The remarks regarding training generally in para. two above are applicable to this Corps. This Corps, during the year under review, did not reach its usual high standard due to training being hampered by the removal of the entire school to a new residence and sickness.
4. COQUALEETZA CADET CORPS.

Coqualeetza Cadet Corps, organized in May, 1926, is situated at Coqualeetza Residential School at Sardis, one mile from Chilliwack in the Fraser Valley, B.C. The training is supervised by the Principal of the School, Rev. G.H. Ray, and instructed by Captain Peter F. Irvine, M.M., a member of the School staff. During the School year 1925-30, 40 Indian boys were enrolled and trained. Training is along the lines of "mass" instruction rather than specialization. Very sound work was evinced at the annual inspection. This Corps received highest marks for efficiency and will receive the new Shield awarded by the I.O.D.E. Provincial Chapter, of B.C.

The general remarks re training referred to in para. two are applicable.

5. CONCLUSION.

The work carried out by the Principals and Instructors concerned has an undoubted value, as an interesting addition to academic studies to students of adolescent age. That the physical education imparted by instructors who have had the advantage of attending the Cadet Instructors' Course in addition to the Normal School Physical Training is thorough, is particularly noticeable to a visiting inspector at once. The advantage of training in First Aid needs no discussion. The inherent interest of the Indian boy to hunt with rifles is made safer by proper instruction in the handling and use of rifles. As stated before, the Indian boy enjoys the training and the results are beneficial.

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the advanced educational grant for Nellie Bent, No. 0114, of the St. George's Indian Residential School.

The account which you forwarded for the advanced educational grant of $50 for the academic year 1934-35 is being paid, and a cheque will reach you in the near future.

It has been decided to allow this girl to continue her high school work during the current academic year, and the advanced educational grant will be allowed for her.

However, at the end of June, next, a report should be obtained from the Principal of the High School which she attends giving full particulars regarding her work during the academic year 1935-36. You should forward this to the Department, and a decision will then be made regarding what assistance, if any, can be allowed for her for the academic year 1936-37.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of 
Rosie Austin, Pupil No. 0156,
of the St. George Indian Residential School at Lytton,
who died at Lytton, B.C., (place) on June 19, 1936.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Honored Sir:

We desire to submit to you the wishes of the Indian Chiefs. They claim that it is a long time since they were told by the first Governor Douglas that they would soon have a school for their children. About forty years have passed away since then and they are still waiting for the fulfillment of that promise. Capilano, the first chief, to whom the promise was made has long since been gathered to his fathers. His son, Lush, was the next chief. He too has gone to his eternal rest without seeing the school promised so long ago to his father.

Now, Sir, it comes to us to respectfully request a fulfillment of that promise.

There are three tribes of Indians interested, the Squamish, the Sechelt and the Sliammon. In these tribes there are now more than 400 children.

We would like to have a Roman Catholic school, convent and college here, at Squamish Mission, where the children can be taught, fed and clothed. The ground is ready to be used for this purpose.

Signed on behalf of the tribes,

Dear Mr. Hall,

I am writing to you in response to your letter dated January 23, 1897. I did not reply promptly to your last statement made to you about the fact that the Hon. Mr. Hall, when visiting our institute, remarked that very few of the 74 children present were of pure Indian blood and that I had difficulty in finding Indian children. This must surely be some mistake, sir. My recollection of what took place is as follows. When the Hon. gentleman was looking over the school, he remarked, "Surely, there are not all of pure Indian blood." I replied, "No, there are several half-breeds," both having the same half-breed mind (for I had never counted them up). He could not be easy to decide between the one class and the other by mere inspection, or without a knowledge of the percentage. I could not tell the Hon. Mr. Hall what proportion each was present. I have a distinct recollection of his intonation and attitude, but cannot explain it now that many of these half-breeds are now elsewhere wards of the government. But before I had time to make a remark to this effect, the Hon. gentleman asked some question respecting the school which I answered. I cannot proceed further at this time because that I had not been able to make the explanations which I felt ought to have been made to prevent misunderstanding which I feared might result from the general and unexplained answer I had given.

The facts are distinguished. Mr. Hall kept up a running fire of questions which indicated his keenness of observation and desire for information. Many of which I was able to give only partial answers before a further question or remark called for reply. I held him so that I had been in charge of the institute only a few months and that the too many matters connected with it that I had not yet become familiar with and it will be seen how possible it was that my partial answers &c., comprehending questions might be misleading when reported from a standpoint that was not at the moment present to my mind. In this respect I did feel that the visit of the Hon. gentleman was unsatisfactory. It was brief and hurried, so strongly impressed was I with this feature of its unsatisfactoriness that I thought seriously of turning questioning him and gathering a more full into explanations and details of fact which it seemed to me had been made necessary by his questions having been so partially answered.

Sincerely yours,

Memorandum

Industrial School needed for the Indians on the Squamish Reserve opposite Vancouver.

In the fall of 1894, the Squamish Indians sent a petition to the Honorable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, the Honorable Mr. Daly, asking for an industrial school on their reserve, opposite the City of Vancouver.

The above petition was seconded by some gentlemen from Vancouver and by me in writing and was forwarded to the Honorable Mr. Daly by Mr. G. E. Carboold, M.C.

A kind reply was made by the Honorable Mr. Daly on the 21st December last, Mr. Carboold, but no promise was given.

At the end of August 1895, the Honorable Mr. Daly came to Vancouver with the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Mr. Hayton Reed. Mr. Reed paid a visit to the Squamish Indians on their reserve opposite Vancouver.

The Squamish Chiefs, seconded by the Chiefs of Dechell, Shannan, Clakes and Kowalbo tribes along the coast, handed to Mr. Reed a second petition asking for the establishment of an industrial school on their reserve. This petition was again addressed to the Honorable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, the Indian Chiefs entrusting Mr. Reed to use his influence in obtaining for them the industrial school they most needed for the education of their children.

Few months after they received a favorable reply through Mr. Superintendent of Indians at Victoria, Mr. Vorwell, and the Agent of Fraser Agency, Mr. Frank Deslin. An industrial school was to be established on their reserve.

To the above communication the Squamish made the following reply:

Five different tribes, named Squamish, Seskelt, Shannan, Cohoes and Komakko, are living on the Mainland Coast from Vancouver to Butte Inlet, in the Western part of the Fraser River Agency. 1. Concerning the Establishing of an Indian Industrial School on the Squamish Reservation, opposite Vancouver.

This is a long felt want. Five different tribes of Indians scattered on the mainland coast from Vancouver to Butte Inlet, in the Fraser River Agency, number 1150 in all. They come often to Vancouver for trading purposes. They have 200 children of school age; not one of them has ever been to school; all are growing up in total ignorance.

These Indians many times appealed to the late government for an industrial school; promises were made but never kept.

In view of promises made, the Indians cleared ten acres of land on their Reserve for a school site, they are still waiting the promised buildings.

These Indians certainly deserve better treatment. They are an exemplary class and should be encouraged. The Squamish Village opposite Vancouver is a model of order and cleanliness for which it is much admired not only by the Citizens of Vancouver but by tourists and strangers.

Therefore I respectfully ask that an appropriation of fifteen thousand dollars be voted by Parliament at next session for the erection of suitable School buildings and that same may be pushed forward at an early date.

2. Concerning a request for a grant of $6,500.00 to St. Mary's Indian Boarding School for fifty pupils.

The grant we receive from the Dominion government for said school is sixty dollars ($60.00) only, for each of sixty pupils ($3,600.00 per annum). I have to complain of this diminutive capitulation grant of sixty dollars per pupil.

Experience has proved that such capitulation is entirely insufficient for providing a pupil with board, clothing, washing, mending, books and stationary, doctor's fees, medicine etc., and keeping the school up to the high standard required by the Government and the parents of the children.

I wish that time permitted you to see St. Mary's school. We have...
Erected at our own expense and at a cost of eighteen thousand dollars two separate school buildings: one for girls under the management of four sisters of St. Ann, the other for boys under the direction of two Fathers and two laymen. There is ample accommodation for forty-five children in each school.

We incurred this large outlay under the impression that the Federal Government would furnish the means of carrying on these schools for the benefit of a Catholic population of 1394 Indians.

A careful census taken this year by my missionaries shows that the Indians living in the valley of the Fraser River from Yale down to its mouth form a population of 1676 souls, 1394 of whom are members of the Catholic Church.

Among these thirteen hundred and ninety-four (1394) Catholic Indians there are now many heads of families who have been educated at St. Mary's Boarding School established in 1861, upwards of thirty-five years ago. They have raised their education in those schools and to those schools they wish to send their children, 77 of whom are there at present.

The golden rule of the Federal government being not to disturb the faith of the Indians but to leave them to the guidance of those who have converted them to Christianity, I firmly hope that the government will help their Catholic Indians to have their children educated in the school of their choice and of their faith and place them there on the same terms as the Indian children are admitted by the government into the Methodist Boarding School of Coqualeetza at Chilliwack.

The Dominion Government having found it advisable to grant six thousand and five hundred dollars for fifty pupils to the Methodist School of Coqualeetza, should grant the same amount for fifty pupils to St. Mary's Catholic School; they are in the same district but 20 miles apart; they are for the same tribe, whose Indians are nearly all Catholics; they give the same common-school industrial education to their pupils. As a proof of St. Mary's School's efficient training, I may mention that the pupils of the Sisters of St. Ann were awarded ten first class and two second class prizes at the Grand Agricultural and Industrial Exhibition held last year at New Westminster.

Therefore in asking for St. Mary's Indian Boarding School a grant of six thousand and five hundred dollars for fifty pupils, I simply ask...
for justice, equality and nothing more, and when the matter is reconsidered, I am satisfied the government will comply with my request and place on the estimates of the year 1897 a grant of six thousand five hundred dollars for St. Mary's Boarding School and have it voted by Parliament on its next session. Though it would be farce, all things considered, to allow the capitulation rate of $130.00 for each of 60 pupils, the number at present paid for at the insufficient rate of $60 dollars per pupil.

Paul Durieu, O.M.I.

In reference to the application for a grant for the establishment of an Industrial school at Squamish B.C., made by His Lordship Bishop Durie,

The undersigned begs to say that there is no school of this class on the Lower Fraser. There is a Roman Catholic boarding school at St Mary's Mission City with provision for 60 pupils at $60 each per annum, and a so-called Industrial School at Chilliwack (Coqualeetza) with provision for 50 pupils at $130, conducted by the Methodist Missionary Society. The Bishop in making his application complains of the increased grant to the Coqualeetza Home.

Although nearly all the Indians of the Lower Fraser are shown by the census returns to belong to the Roman Catholic faith, the proportion being about 10 to 1, they have no Industrial school.

The undersigned thinks that if increased provision could be made for St Mary's Mission, another Roman Catholic school would not be required on the Lower Fraser.

Hereunder is a memorandum from Mr. Benson respecting the application for a grant to a school at Squamish, Burrard's Inlet. I observe that in a letter of the 4th December, 1897, Mr. Vowell recommended that the Bishop's proposal be accepted, as he considered that the terms offered were most reasonable and as he knew "that the Indians in that locality are anxiously looking for the fulfilment of the promise made to them to that end some time ago by Mr. Hayter Reed when he visited the Coast as Deputy Superintendent General."

I find that in September, 1896, a petition was received from the Chiefs of the tribes of the Squamish Mission in which it was set forth that the school had been promised forty years ago by Governor Douglas and they were still waiting for it, and in which it was asked that a convent and college should be founded "where the children could be taught, fed and clothed." Mr. Reed acknowledged this petition in these words:

"I beg to inform you that your application is approved of, and an item to provide for a school at that place will..."
will be inserted in the estimates which it is hoped will be passed by Parliament."

Naturally the Indians inferred that something in the nature of a boarding school was to be established, and in a communication of the 20th November, 1897, the Chiefs expressed their pleasure and asked that the school be made large enough to accommodate at least 150 children; they intimated that the Indians were so pleased that they had put themselves at once to clear 20 acres of land which they had selected and reserved as a site for the school.

On receipt of this communication Mr. Keed wrote Mr. Vowell to disabuse the Indians of their impression of the character of the proposed school as he had acted under the impression that it was a day school that was asked for.

Whatever may have been Mr. Keed's impression, the Indians made a very clear request for a school in which their children would live, and he as clearly expressed in writing his approval in addition to the verbal promise he made according to Mr. Vowell's statement; and no explanation which could be offered will ever convince these Indians that they have been dealt with in good faith.

I venture to submit that the Department having so far committed itself, the best course to pursue would be to act upon Bishop Durien's proposal to build and equip a boarding school upon the Department's providing the usual contribution for sixty pupils. I don't think we can make any increase in the boarding school rate unless we are prepared to increase the rate all round.

Sir:

I have the honor to report, as directed by you, regarding the petition sent to the Department by the Squamish Indians requesting the conversion of the Indian Boarding School at Squamish into an Industrial School.

I visited the institution on Friday March 17, inspected the pupils and the premises very carefully, and found all clean bright, and in good condition. But for the following reasons I could not recommend the Department to grant the prayer of the petition:

First—I do not consider the situation suitable for an Industrial School. Not sufficient land, there being only 14 acres, and only part of that suitable for cultivation, and this is close to the City limits of North Vancouver, which is building up very fast, and an Industrial School is not best so close to a town. Then, as is the case with the Indians on the False Creek Reserve, I fear it will only be a short time before the town people of North Vancouver will agitate for the removal of these Indians from their town, thus to spend a large sum of money there would be unwise.

Secondly—The present buildings are not sufficient to carry on an Industrial School, and suitable out-buildings would be required.

Thirdly—The Principal and Staff do not wish the change to be made, and the Indians presented the petition without their knowledge.
The parents, well to do, who have children in the Boarding-School, are supposed to occasionally supply shoes and stockings, and, once in a while, articles of clothing. The Indians would like to be relieved of this, and think that the enlarged grant for an Industrial School would release them from further help.

The Squamish Boarding School is doing excellent work, the children are small, and I would respectfully recommend that it be continued as a Boarding-School.

Should the Department desire to establish an Industrial School in this Agency, St. Mary's Mission on the Fraser, is in my opinion the place. A Boarding School has been operated there, for the welfare of the Indians for many years; where there is sufficient good land, and very substantial buildings. The Deputy Superintendent General,

I beg to inform you that on October 5, last I made an inspection of the Squamish Boarding School located at North Vancouver, B.C.

The buildings are of frame, the original building being very old and in very poor condition generally.

A new building annexed to original building has recently been erected and is a fairly substantial structure in good condition excepting the upper or dormitory story which shows signs of settlement and the plastering is badly cracked.

No system of ventilation has been attempted except through the windows which can usually be left open for ventilation purposes during the entire year.

The plumbing, etc., in the new portion of the building is modern and the work fairly well done. The number of fixtures installed are insufficient and should be increased particularly the wash basin.

The school has an ample system of drainage and is connected with city water supply.

There is a good laundry in connection with the school the equipment being about complete.

Although the building is somewhat elevated above the earth no basement has been provided the frame being erected on posts.

I have the honour to draw Your Grace's attention to existing conditions at the Squamish Mission Indian Boarding School.

On August 2nd this institution was visited by the Departmental Inspector and an enrolment of 70 pupils was reported. The Department provides a grant for 50 pupils and an examination of the building made sometime ago shows that there is only accommodation for 46.

North Vancouver Indian Boarding School.

School opened January 1879, in a small wood building put up by Indians under direction of late Bishop Laverie.

School enlarged same year at the Sisters' expense. Four years later, 1883, a new wing was added again at the Sisters' expense too.

At the present time the building is too small to accommodate all the children of the tribe; though 50 enrolled, there are about 20 of age to be admitted that we cannot accept for want of room.

For these 25 years the Sisters have furnished lodging to an average of 50 children with the only help of the Grant per Child, which hardly covers the food expenses. Meanwhile the school has been burdened with heavy taxes and the Sisters receiving no salary have been obliged to work like slaves to make the two ends meet.

If the Government does not want to build a new school the Sisters wish the Department to pay them a salary with which they would be able to make the necessary improvements. Otherwise the staff cannot continue the work under such circumstances.

I have the honour to report that I presided at a regular meeting of the Squamish Indian Council at the Mission Reserve, North Vancouver, on July 15th ult., whereat I was requested by the Council to address a letter to you as follows:

"It is the understanding of the Council from conversation with Mr. Andrew Paull, Council Secretary, who recently visited Ottawa on business, that the Department would be willing to consider a proposal to erect a new Indian Residential School to replace the one now existing at North Vancouver, B.C. and known as Squamish Indian Residential School.

The Council is informed by Mr. Paull that the Reverend Sisters of the Child Jesus, now conducting the residential school at North Vancouver, are owners of a piece of land in area approximately twenty-five acres near Capilano on the outskirts of North Vancouver, and that Mr. Neish has another area of fifty acres adjoining that of the Reverend Sisters which he may be willing to sell.

The Council understands that when the building now in use as a residential school at North Vancouver was first erected, it was then intended that that building should be used for school purposes for only five years, and that probably by that time an up-to-date fire-proof building may be erected. It is believed that the present building has been in use for nearly thirty years and is becoming more and more decayed, the foundations are caving in in places, and the building is regarded more or less as a fire trap. The present building is a wooden frame building.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th inst. advising me that the pupils of Squamish Residential School had been provided for at $5 and the per capita grant raised to $70.00.

I have hesitated to make any unpleasant representations regarding this School but this increase in grant gives me the opportunity of pointing out that the pupils are insufficiently fed, and respectfully suggest that any increase is contingent upon a great improvement in this respect.

It is difficult to keep a close check on the food supply as officials are courteously but none the less effectually prevented from any close investigation and one is naturally desirous of avoiding any unpleasantness with the reverend principal who has been in charge so long.

The only meal I have actually seen was one at mid-day which consisted of a piece of bread and a raw carrot. It may have been a fast day, and I have not since been successful in actually seeing a meal on the table.

Mr. William of Squamish Reserve advised me that he sent his son to the school and in one month lost ten pounds in weight and stated that during this time was not given a bath. The Chief is quite reliable but the boy may have exaggerated about the lack of a bath.

Andrew Paulll states that children whose parents live on Mission Reserve run home at recess to get food. He asked me to report on this matter but he exaggerates everything so much that he defeats his own object. If even a tenth of his statements were correct, the situation needs remedying.

Miss Gerry, travelling nurse has the same difficulty as I have in investigating anything at the School and she reports that the food supply is unsatisfactory.

Mr. G. Barry, Inspector of Schools, who recently made his first visit to Squamish School, reported that the children should have more milk and eggs so evidently the appearance of the children prompted this report as I did not see him before he visited the School.

If the Principal has not already been advised of the increase in grant I respectfully suggest that she be advised that it is conditional upon her giving Miss Gerry full authority and co-operation in examining the food at any time. If there is nothing to be remedied, the Principal can have no objection.

I have the honour to be,

Sir

Your obedient servant

(F.J.C.Ball)

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant advising me that the pupilage of Squamish Residential School could not be increased as requested to sixty.

I have duly received your advice of July 14th, File 167-1-3, instructing me that the pupilage had been raised to 55 and the per capita grant to $170.00. The School authorities have been so advised and also that it was contingent upon an improvement in the food supply. I may say that the Principal, the Reverend Sister Mary Amy, is absent on extended leave and the acting principal is co-operating whole-heartedly in this matter. The milk and egg supply have been doubled and meat is now given at least once and sometimes twice a day. Vegetables and fruit have also been increased and if the present standard is maintained, the children will be well fed. The Principal advises me that she is distinctly disappointed that the pupilage is not raised to sixty and they have re-arranged class rooms and sleeping accommodation so that a number of orphans can be accommodated. The Principal says that when the Deputy Minister visited the school last, they were advised that if room could be found for sixty pupils, the grant would be raised accordingly. I do not know when this took place, certainly not since I have been agent here so I am only repeating the Principal's statement.

However, if your decision could possibly be re-considered in view of the number of applicants awaiting admission and the pupilage raised to 60, it would take care of some deserving cases. Of course there are always four or five at school who do not show on the quarterly returns and for whom no application for admission is made. There are always a few cases which they feel compelled to accept without extra payment.

As was to be expected, School Inspector Mr. G.H. Barry, advised the Principal that bathing facilities were inadequate and to ask for further accommodation. There is only one bath for about thirty boys and the Principal has applied for another bath for the boys. There are two baths for the girls. Personally I consider three shower baths would be more suitable in every way and would not take up any more room than one bath. I mention this as the Principal is writing you direct in the matter.

Sir:-

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter received from the Principal of the Squamish Residential School, North Vancouver, which is self-explanatory.

The Sisters have erected a fine building near the school where except for the usual night staff on duty, they will reside, thus leaving space in the school which has been taken up by living quarters. The new building is advertised to have cost $55,000.00 and is much larger than the school itself.

I realize the necessity of conserving funds in each department, and on this account am forwarding the request without recommendation. The school building is old, and the greatest care has to be exercised at all times to prevent fire.

The standard of education here has presumably been reported upon favourably by the school inspector but in my opinion it is not much use for boys over ten years to attend a school managed by Sisters. This is no reflection on the Squamish School Sisters who are all earnest, hardworking ladies, but the boys turned out from the school are undisciplined and generally of little account afterwards. They do pretty much as they please at school and need the firmer hand of male control. I think the Sisters realize this too, although I have never discussed the matter with them.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent.

General: Per Capita Grant is at present being drawn for 55 children. I have recommended in an earlier part of this report several changes in partitions in classrooms and dormitories. These should be undertaken in any case; but should they be completed there will be available accommodation in the way of sleeping and classroom space for an additional 15 children.

The Roman Catholic Missionary in North Vancouver has had a long talk to me about the state of things on the Indian Reserve there. He informs me that there are more than sufficient children to fill this school if so increased in accommodation. I wish particularly to recommend that the number of pupils authorized to draw Per Capita Grant here be increased to a total of 70. This will take care of those who should be resident in the school, and make it possible for the Church to carry on this school without loss, while at the same time feeding the children in a proper manner. It must be remembered that there are no cows here and milk as well as many of the other foods must be purchased.

MS. G. C. PERRY, INDIAN COMMISSIONER FOR B.C., IN FORWARDING MR. INSPECTOR BARRY'S REPORT, COMMENTS AS FOLLOWS:

Increased per Capita and Pupilage:

For the reasons above mentioned, and in view of the present state of the residential school building, with its inadequate accommodation, it is considered that the suggestion to increase the pupilage of this school is involved more or less in and should be approached in connection with the question of a more adequate building as petitioned for by the Indians. The building has often been referred to as a "death-trap" and "fire-trap" and what not? Why increase the number of resident pupils under these conditions? To patch up this old building and to carry out the suggestions of the resident Missionary, laudable as they may seem, would be but a make-shift, resulting in less efficiency and larger expense.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated September 7th, instant, covering copy of your letter of the same date, No.167-1-1, addressed by you to Mr. F.J.C. Ball, Indian Agent at Vancouver, in regard to the proposal to close the Squamish Indian Residential School at North Vancouver.

In reply I beg to say that reply to your letter has been deferred for a short time pending the inspection of the school by the District Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, as I had understood from Inspector Barry that he would be making his regular inspection and I preferred to await the result of his observations and consider them before replying to your letter.

I now have the honor to transmit herewith Inspector Barry's letter of September 28th, instant, together with his report, the contents of which will, it is thought, enable you to decide whether or not it would be agreeable to the Department that the Church authorities should be approached with a view to ascertaining on what terms their new building could be acquired, on the one hand and, on the other hand, what arrangements could best be suggested with respect to the termination of the residential school and the adoption of a day school system, in the event of the Department abiding by its decision to discontinue the use of the old building, or being unable to provide a modern residential school building of its own.

From my own experience as Indian Agent for seven years in the Vancouver Agency I believe that Inspector Barry has stated the position very fairly and sincerely. I gathered, however, from our recent conversation during your trip to Victoria that a change of educational policy was being contemplated by the Department in which the Indian Day School system would probably in the future be emphasized in preference to the expenditure of heavier expenditures on residential school maintenance and operation. It is not quite clear to me why the proposal to close the Squamish Residential School is related in any way to the policy referred to or if such closure is wholly on account of the reported condition of the old building. As the latter appears to be the case, it is considered that the reshingling and improvements to the old building which have been recently done as recited by the Inspector would seem to justify the Department at least in permitting the reverend Sisters to carry on at the old building for a sufficiently suitable time in which to enjoy the benefit of these improvements.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

I can...
I can say without hesitation that during my tenure of office at Vancouver I was greatly pleased with the excellent service given at this school. The general progress, the homelike atmosphere, the kindly treatment of the children, the generally carefree demeanour of the pupils as well as the absence of trouble such as truancy or lack of discipline were marked features of this institution. The Inspector has found similar conditions there and has reported on them. For these reasons I feel quite reluctant to recommend any drastic changes that would possibly leave the Sisters beyond the pale of some form of recompense by way of ensuring the continuity of their school work if they are disposed to carry on under the Department's policies and direction.

I shall be pleased to discuss the situation fully with Mr. Agent Ball and with the Sisters at North Vancouver, but before doing so I would like to have, if possible, the reaction of the Department to Inspector Barry's report and suggestions, so that the matter might be approached from the Department's viewpoint.

The matter of erecting one or two Indian day schools would, in my opinion, have to be carefully approached, inasmuch as it would involve a survey of the children who attend the residential school and of the conditions under which they would have to be cared for if the residential school were closed, and such day schools established in its stead.

While Inspector Barry and I are in favor of Indian day schools being placed in certain reserves under favorable conditions, it should be pointed out that the nearness of the Squamish reserves to the Cities of North Vancouver and Greater Vancouver makes it necessary to safeguard the pupils by giving them the best possible supervision and care, and up to now the residential school has afforded this protection.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Squamish Indian Residential School, Vancouver Agency, which I inspected on September 22nd last.

This report has been made with great care, and deals more with the future of the educational work in North Vancouver than with the classroom activities, the term's work having only lately been started.

As you will see from my report I have to recommend the taking over of the new building owned by the Sisters of the Child Jesus if the Department will not permit the work of the Residential School to be continued in the old Residential School. This latter building has been lately repaired and reroofed, and is I believe in good structural condition for some years to come.

I am quite unable to recommend the erection of one or more Day Schools in the Vancouver Agency, as such schools would not be able to supply the peculiar needs of the children at present attending the Residential School.

CLASSROOM

Condition of Classrooms (Ventilation, light, etc.)

The classrooms are ventilated by the windows.

The Intermediate and Primary Rooms are now located in the old building, and the Senior Room is in the Auditorium Building.

The new Primary Room is located in what used to be the Senior Classroom in the old building before this room was divided under the instructions of the Indian Agent. The work there undertaken was never satisfactory, and has been removed to make the present Primary Room. This room has also been freshly decorated inside, has six large windows, a Blackboard of about 26 x 18 feet (a careful tally made morning and afternoon) and is itself about 38 feet by 40 feet.

The large room used by the Primary Children last year, in the Auditorium Building is now used by the Senior Grades, and is a great improvement on the small room at the head of the stairs used by these grades last year. The Intermediate Grades are in the same room as last year.

These changes have solved the various difficulties with regard to classroom accommodation mentioned in my last report.

The Classroom Registers are kept with very great care.

General: This is a very good group. The teacher has very good control; but is a little old fashioned in her method of handling the class.

Primary Room: Teacher Sister M. Catherine. 35 Single Desks.

Grades 1A and 1B

Reading: Reading has just been started with the Beginners of Grade 1B. They know about 25 words. They are using a very poor Primer called Two Little Indians, supplied by the Department. I have used white boards to teach with such poor material without other means, and the teacher is using Blackboard methods which I demonstrated to her last year. Grade 1A are reading the Corona Primer very well indeed and will finish Primer 2 by the end of December. Some other Readers will then be necessary; but the Department does not seem to supply the books I state are necessary, so I do not know just what to do. This class should read six or seven short First Readers during the year. AND THIS IS A MINIMUM. Dr. Gates suggests between 15 and 30 during the last few months in Grade 1.

Number Work: Grade 1B are reading and writing the numbers to 12. Grade 1A are working the Combinations and Separations to 10. The Department has supplied books called Individual Arithmetic Books A & B, for this Room; but these books are nearly useless, as the work is not taken up in the recognized manner, the Combinations being quite separated from the Separations instead of being linked with them just as closely as is possible.

Health: There is nothing further to report under this heading at the present time. The health of the children has been good.

Laundry: There is a definite lack of drying accommodation at this school; but I am not prepared to make a recommendation for the expenditure of funds on this at the present time. The Sisters have provided a new electric washing machine since my last report. There are twelve old and ten new tubs in use for the washing of the clothes.

Fire Protection:

With reference to my last report under this head, I may say that I am informed by the Matron that the Fire Chief on one of his visits to the school told the Sisters that the Fire Buckets were not of much or any use. They have therefore been discarded. I should like to see these buckets kept filled with water, and placed in suitable positions about the building. There are eight Soda Type Extinguishers, which the Fire Chief has tested I believe. They were refilled in March last by the Janitor. Fire Drills are held regularly. The Fire Chief inspects about once a month.

Dormitories: The Dormitories are all very neat and perfectly clean. A new small dormitory for six of the little girls has been fitted up. The dormitory used by the little boys is rather crowded, there being 12 beds (two of which are not in use at the present time) and a Sisters bed in a room of about 25 feet by 20 feet and of average height of perhaps 10 feet. I do not think that more than the ten being used by the boys at present should be left here, the other two being moved to the other boys' dormitory, even if that room is fairly full now.

Dining Rooms: I still consider that the children are being fed in a very satisfactory manner, and would refer the Department to previous reports if any information is required at the present time about the food. I am informed that my advice about more milk has been acted on, and that the children receive at least a cup of milk each day.

Farming: There are about three acres of garden and orchard, which is very well cared for by the gardener, and the boys. Fruits and vegetables of all sorts are grown and used by the children in the school.

Clothing: The children are well dressed in suitable clothes. These children are as well dressed, and probably better dressed, than is the case in any other Indian school in B.C.

Kitchen: This is clean. There is nothing to add to previous reports.

Water Supply: The water supply is abundant, and is of first rate quality as it is supplied from the North Vancouver City mains. The pressure is of course good.

Light: The lighting is by electricity supplied from the North Vancouver City mains.

Heating: The three hot air furnaces in the basement supply sufficient heat to the different parts of the old building. The Auditorium Building is heated by a large wood burning heater.

General:
Per Capita Grant is at present being drawn for up to 55 children. I wish to again refer the Department to the recommendations contained in my last report. All the milk and a large quantity of the foodstuffs have to be purchased. Should it be decided to move any of the Indian parents to other parts of the Indian Reserves additional children will probably have to be provided for at this Residential School. I should certainly like to see the numbers entitled to draw Per Capita at this school increased to 70 as reported in my previous report on the school. The school is being conducted in a very satisfactory manner indeed by the Sisters of the Child Jesus. These Sisters have made every effort to follow my suggestions for the better administration of the school. I have never been able to accept the views held by the local Indian Agent with regard to this school. He has told me that he considers that amongst others the Squamish Indian Residential School should be closed. Why I am quite unable to imagine, as it is one of the best small Indian Residential Schools in this Province. I am informed by the Assistant Indian Commissioner that the Department is considering closing this school as from the end of June 1934, and have therefore the following recommendation to make for the information of the Department.
General Recommendation:

Though the old school building here is not very well arranged for a school, the newly shingled roof, and the newly arranged Primary Classroom, make it possible to carry on the school in these buildings for a number of years still. The foundations have been repaired as reported at various times and the school is kept in a perfectly sanitary and neat state. The Manual Training and Senior Grades are accommodated in the Auditorium Building, which belongs, I understand, to the Indians. The original building of this school was constructed in a solid manner, and I have every reason to believe that it will last another eight or ten years at least.

The question arises as to what should be done with the children should the Department close the present Residential School. In my opinion the provision of a three room Day School, or of several Day Schools, would in no way take the place of the present Residential School. Six of the children come from the Musqueam Indian Reserve, Point Grey, and there are a number of Indians and children from homes where they can not be properly looked after, at present in this school. The provision of suitable Day Schools is in my opinion quite out of the question, as it would take a three room school in North Vancouver, and probably two other one room schools to absorb the children, and then the orphans, etc., would not be accommodated.

I wish to strongly recommend that the school be continued as at present till the Department finds itself in a position to build a new school for these Indian children, such school to be a modern Residential School to accommodate about 100 children.

If the Department will not consider such a course as that outlined in the last paragraph, I would recommend that negotiations be entered into with the Sisters of the Child Jesus, and the Roman Catholic Church to take over for the time being the new building just completed on a site adjoining the old school. This new building is of cement and brick veneer construction, and has been completed this year at a cost of about $50,000.00. A photograph of this building which has been designed as a PRIVATE SCHOOL and CONVENT is attached for information. I have inspected the whole of this new building on two separate occasions and consider that there would be plenty of room for sixty children. There are two classrooms divided by folding doors, two large dormitories, a smaller dormitory and a number of small rooms for either senior children or the Sisters. There is a very fine set of administration offices, and the usual dining rooms and kitchens, etc. The whole building is of modern design, and splendidly fitted for a School, for which of course it was designed. I am of the opinion that very satisfactory arrangements might be made with the Sisters to lease this building for the time being, till a new Indian Residential School be erected.

I am quite unable to recommend the expenditure of public funds on the construction of one or more Day Schools at the present time in this locality. I do wish to strongly recommend the taking over of the new building from the Sisters of the Child Jesus on terms satisfactory to them and the Department.
October 7, 1933.
