Sr.:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 7th last requesting a report on the Squamish Reserve School building.

This building has two class rooms 27'x30' and 21'x30' respectively, a kitchen, four dormitories, two dining-rooms for the children and one dining-room for the priest on Mission Reserve who boards at the School. There are also a chapel and several other small rooms used for reception, sewing, office, etc.

It is heated by three furnaces, two are in good condition, one will need renewing shortly. A new furnace was installed last Winter.

The building is on city light, water and sewage systems.

The Sister of Instruction of the Child Jesus own the building and have charge of the school, the Reverend Mother Amy being principal since the School was built.

It was built in 1898 and opened in 1899. There are three bath-rooms which are decidedly inadequate. There are four wooden fire-escapes, two being ladders. It is of frame construction, is in poor condition and foundations are unsound. The building was re-shingled last month, the cost being paid from the grant. There are fifty-eight children in residence, evenly divided between boys and girls, and ranging in age from six to sixteen. There is also a day school, the class room being in the Auditorium building built four or five years ago from Squamish Band funds. This is detached from the main building as are also the laundry and living quarters of the Sisters.

Of the fifty-eight children boarding at the School, forty have one or both parents living on the Reserves at North Vancouver—Mission, Capilano or Burrard, six are from Musqueam Reserve, six from distant reserves and six are orphans or have been abandoned by their mothers. Of the forty who have parents on the reserves adjacent to the school, about one-half of them have no mother to take care of them either because of death, or living with another man than her husband, or in the insane asylum, or too sick. These children have fathers living on the Reserve.

If the residential school is closed, the auditorium referred to above would be large enough to take care of all the present pupils as day scholars, certain alterations....

Harold W. McGill, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
alterations, not extensive, would be necessary and presumably the permission of the Squamish Band would have to be obtained. The space in this building is at present wasted to a large extent. The manual training class use one room which is more than twice as large as necessary and other rooms are seldom used at all.

The Musqueam Indians have no school. There are twenty-four children of school age in this Band, about half of them being scattered among various schools. A small day school would take care of these.

If the neglected, orphaned or otherwise uncared for children of Squamish Residential School could be accommodated elsewhere, the situation might be met by a small school being built and equipped on Musqueam Reserve, and the auditorium used as a day school, then the present residential building could be abandoned. If the auditorium can not be used, a new day school building could be erected for $5,000.00. The Musqueam School would cost approximately $1,500.00.

The two day schools would need at least three teachers, one of them at Musqueam, the other two at Mission No.1. This would mean that the parent or parents would have to support about forty of the children at present in residence at the school.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Re: Squamish Indian Residential School.

Accompanied by Mr. Agent Ball, I visited this school on June 17th.

As the Department is aware, it is an old building, but the Reverend Sisters have made several repairs this year, such as relining the back of the building to make it warmer and painting the whole building. The interior of the building is spotlessly clean.

The children seemed healthy and happy.

At one time all the Sisters resided in the school building, but recently a new building has been built as a residence for the Sisters, and the majority of the staff is now living in this separate residence. There is, therefore, more space in the school, and, as they have no trouble in obtaining children, the Sister Superior requested that the pupilage be increased from 55 to 60. I informed her that this could not be done just now but that she might write next Spring.
Sir:

I have received a request from the Squamish Residential School that I ask the Department to increase the grant paid them from $5 to $60, as they have 62 in residence, and have had over 60 for many months. They say this matter was discussed with Mr. Phelan when he visited the School, and that he recommended that they apply for the increased grant for the coming fiscal year.

The Sisters have recently expended rather a large amount of money on improvements at the School, both inside and out. In a separate report I am placing before the Department their request that shower baths be installed, as the bathing facilities are extremely limited.

The matter of an increased grant has been taken up before as you will no doubt recollect, but in view of the above circumstances, it is being again placed before you for your consideration.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I have the honour to report that Reverend Mother Amy called today and resigned as Principal of Squamish Indian Residential School, which is owned by the Sisters of the Child Jesus.

Mother Amy has completed 40 years in charge of this School which she opened with 9 pupils in 1899, and on account of advanced age wishes to be relieved of the business management which for the past six years has been in the hands of Sister Alix, who will succeed her as Principal, if approved by you.

Mother Amy will remain in the Convent adjoining the Reserve and continue her interest in the School. She has endeared herself to several generations of Indians, besides all who come in contact with her, and I believe the Department would wish to show some official recognition of her long and faithful services.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant enclosing Inspector Barry's report regarding his inspection of the Squamish Residential School on January 23 last.

The report has been carefully considered and the following action should be taken at once:

1. Inspector Barry and yourself should interview the Reverend Mother Provincial of the Sisters of the Child Jesus at an early date and arrange with her to nominate a competent Principal to take charge of this school.

2. At the time of your visit to the Mother Provincial you should point out that the Department must insist on adequate wooden fire escapes being erected at the earliest possible date.

3. The Reverend Mother Provincial and the Principal of the school should be advised that the enrolment must be reduced to a number approximating that for which grant is provided; namely, 60.

With reference to No. 1, I may say that in addition to the contents of Inspector Barry's report the Department has noted that there have been several cases of truancy at this school in the past month or so. While truancy is not always the fault of the school management at the same time our experience shows that in the majority of instances there is some laxity at a residential school when several cases of truancy occur within a comparatively short period.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,

Regarding No. 2 and No. 3 the Department has in mind the fact that this is a very old building and consequently there must be considerable fire hazard in spite of the many precautions that are no doubt taken. Yours truly,

Dear Major MacKay:

In accordance with your previous instructions I visited the Convent of the Sisters of the Child Jesus in North Vancouver yesterday, August 6th, and had a long conference with the Provincial Superior, Rev. Mother Gabriel and Sister Mary Alix, Principal of the Squamish Indian Residential School.

The reasons leading to my submission of a report on this school under date of January 26, 1940 portions of which were of an adverse nature were gone into with care.

The Reverend Sisters agreed with me that there was reason for the adverse nature of at least part of my report. They pointed out however that since I reported on their school the following changes had been made:

(1) New fire escapes had been constructed.
(2) The number of pupils in residence had been reduced.
(3) The Sister in charge of the supervision of the boys had been sent to another school and a better qualified Sister placed in her position.

In the above ways the Sisters had done their best to carry out the wishes of the Department and improve the conditions complained of in my report.

It was further pointed out to me that Sister M. Alix had been named as Principal of the Squamish Indian Residential School to replace Rev. Mother M. Amy before the latter had been recalled as Provincial by the appointment of Rev. Mother Gabriel. I was further informed that under the ordinary rules of the Community the nomination of Sister M. Alix as Principal of the residential school and Superior of the Sisters there was for a period of three years.

I explained to the Rev. Mother and Sister Alix that I was satisfied with the changes which had been made to carry into effect the wishes of the Department, and that as far as I was concerned I should not press for the nomination of a new Principal.

The Rev. Mother Gabriel is writing to the Department a brief report of my visit and asking I understand that Sister M. Alix be permitted to remain Principal of the Squamish Residential School for the balance of the three years of her term.

Under the circumstances and considering the changes made in the school administration, appointment of a new boys' supervisor, etc., I would recommend that Sister Alix be permitted to remain Principal of the school.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

Some weeks ago you asked me to make a brief survey of the pupilage of the Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools to determine whether or not the children involved could be accommodated in a Consolidated Day School.

The attached nominal rolls of the children now attending the Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools have been prepared for me by the Reverend Sister Mary Alix, Principal of the schools in question. The following are summaries which it is hoped will be of assistance to you and the Department in coming to a decision in this matter.

The Squamish Day School pupils attend the Residential School classes and as far as academic work is concerned, receive exactly the same education.

At present there are twelve boys and fourteen girls in attendance at the Squamish Day School, while in the Residential School there are twenty-seven boys and thirty-four girls. The classification of these children by grades is as follows:

| Girls | 5 | 1 | 1 | 5 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 1 |

It will be seen from the above that the children are fairly evenly distributed between the grades, with the majority of the Residential School pupils in the primary grades.

It is of extreme importance in considering the possibility of the establishment of a Consolidated Day School to take the place of the present Day and Residential Schools to consider the home conditions of the children at present on the roll of the Squamish Indian Residential School. From the above it will be easily seen that at least half of the boys and about one-third of the girls need Residential School care in any case.

The following tabulation will give a clear picture of the location of the homes from which the Residential School pupilage is drawn:

|                | Burrard Inlet | Squamish Mission #1 | Squamish River Musqueam | Uncertain |
|----------------|---------------|---------------------|-------------------------|-----------|
| Boys           | 5             | 13                  | 1                       | 8         |
| Girls          | 7             | 19                  | 3                       | 3         |

Briefly, I may say that Burrard #3 Reserve is located in or near the Lynn Valley District, some eight miles from the present Squamish Residential School. There are good roads joining these places. The Musqueam Reserve is located near Point Grey, some fifteen miles from the present Squamish school, on the Vancouver city side of Burrard Inlet. Transportation of the Musqueam children to a Consolidated School at Squamish would involve far too great a distance and also the crossing of the new Lions Gate Suspension Bridge. Squamish River Indian Reserve is located at the head of Burrard Sound, some forty miles by water from North Vancouver. Where Squamish is given as the location of the home, it should be understood that this includes the local Reserves in the vicinity of the present Squamish Indian Residential School.

Attached you will find a roll of ten children discharged from the Squamish Residential School during the past year, all these children were fifteen years of age or over. Two were in Grade 4, two in Grade 5, three in Grade 6, and three in Grade 8 at the time of discharge. These children would appear to have received on the average a satisfactory training in the academic subjects.

I regret that it is quite impossible for me to recommend the establishment of a consolidated improved Day School in North Vancouver to take the place of the present Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools. Two main reasons may be given for this conclusion:

1. It would be practically impossible to arrange for the satisfactory transportation of the children involved when the distance to the Musqueam and Burrard #3 Reserves are taken into account. In no system of consolidation could the children from the Squamish River Reserve be included.

2. A very large proportion of the children at present receiving their education at the Squamish Indian Residential School are exactly those who, from the nature of their home and family conditions, must of necessity receive their education at a Residential School.

I trust that the above information will be of assistance to you and to the Department in coming to a final decision and that the present Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools may be allowed to continue to function as such.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

January 4, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of October 29th regarding the suggestion that a consolidated, improved day school be established on the north shore to take the place of the existing Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools.

The possibilities in this connection have been carefully considered and the whole question fully discussed with Inspectors Barry and Coleman.

Inspector Barry's report, together with a sketch plan of the Reserves served by the existing arrangements, is attached.

Owing to the widely scattered character of the Reserves from which the pupilage is drawn, the proposed consolidation would not be practicable. Moreover, a large percentage of the children would, in any event, require residential school care because of unfavorable home and family conditions.

It will be recalled that the establishment of a Day School on the Musqueam Reserve to care for those children for whom there is no room in the Squamish Residential School has been provided for in the 1941-42 Estimates on Departmental instructions.

I would recommend that the existing arrangements be continued.

Yours faithfully,

During a meeting of the Squamish Indian Council on the 24th instant, the Chief and Secretary spoke to me during an interval regarding the training of the Indian school children in farming - not with any idea of making farmers of them, but that they would take more interest in using any arable land on their Reserves for vegetables, feed, etc., and for raising smaller domestic animals.

Our Reserves in this Agency are not suitable for farming as a livelihood as they are too small and much of the land is rocky hillside.

They mentioned that although the present school owned by a religious order is unsuitable for such instruction having been built in the City of North Vancouver, the time has come for a new school to be built as that school is over 40 years old, is a frame building and antiquated, with no proper place for exercise or play, and because of its construction is a great danger from fire. It is also too near the Reserve and too near the Cities of Vancouver and North Vancouver which means that the pupils are able to play truant without much opportunity of stopping it.

The Squamish Band has a large Reserve of 4046 acres at Chekamus No.11 about 55 miles from North Vancouver. There is enough good land on this Reserve which could be used for farming instruction, and the School would be far enough from the Reserve that the children would be under better control.

I advised the Chief and Secretary that there was not much hope of new construction at present, but promised to bring the matter before you for consideration if and when the building of new Residential Schools is contemplated. If some reply to their enquiry could be given, it will be appreciated. This matter was not discussed by the Council as a whole, as it was thought to be one which should not be publicised at the present time.

Indian Agent

COPY SENT TO COMMISSIONER MacKAY
My dear Mr. Phelan:

This is a small school and in very poor condition. It gives the impression of an orphan long neglected, if not completely abandoned, by its foster parents. Had it been in the hands of any other group of workers but a community of Reverend Sisters, I doubt if it would not be, after these many years, in complete ruin.

It is possible that your Commissioner has been hoping for a new school, but knowing the attitude of the Minister's office, I doubt if this will ever come to pass. Under the circumstances, I think the building is worth saving and should be completely repaired. This, I think, can be done for around $6,000 to $8,000, and the Department should not hesitate in providing this amount in the next year's estimates.

For the present, school desks and sewing machines should be replaced as needed and the per capita grant should be increased by 15 pupils. This would provide adequate education for children who are now asking for admission and who cannot be accepted on account of the difficulty of feeding and clothing an extra 15 pupils, when no funds for such purpose are provided by the Indian Department.

I do not think that the grant is up to standard, although I am not sure about the matter. But should I be right, I think you would do well to raise it immediately to conform with other schools of your Department.

The library should also receive some attention as the books are very few in numbers and not of a quality to interest children in the formative years.

(over...)
The Sisters have been very patient with the Department and have not asked what it was their right to expect in the matter of yearly grants for general repairs, and I think that this attitude on their part should not be forgotten.

Thanking you in anticipation I remain,

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Relative to the above mentioned subject, please be advised that a complaint was received at this office during the PM of the 3rd inst. to the effect the St. Paul's Indian Residential School at North Vancouver had been broken into the night or early morning of the last inst.; at which time a quantity of goods had been stolen.

2. A patrol was made immediately to the School, and a check revealed that the locker-room adjoining the kitchen had been broken into through a narrow window on the North side of the building. Dents in the casing of the window signified that an iron tool or bar had been used to break away the casing so that the window could be opened. The Principal of the School advised that a close check of the stock in the cooler and the kitchen revealed that 10 lbs. butter, 4 lbs lard, 8 jars peanut butter, 2 can syrup (5 lb. size), 3 boxes weiners, 2 meat loaves, & 10 2 lb. packages of Br. Sugar had been stolen. It appeared evident that the only motive behind this S.E. was the fact that food-stuffs were the only thing stolen or tampered with; which gave rise to the suspicion that none other than Indians were likely to have perpetrated this offence.

3. Questioning of the School staff, and other persons who reside adjacent to the School revealed nothing of a tangible nature. However, the janitor of the School advised that he had heard from some of the pupils of the School, that two young Indians namely Archie Gonzales & Roger Guss had committed the offence, it was not possible to gather any information to substantiate this however.

4. The B.C. Provincial Police detachment at North Vancouver, B.C. were contacted, who advised that they had received the complaint on the last inst., but had as yet not been able to gather any information which would indicate who had committed the offence. Arrangements were made with this Force to make a check of the Reserve at North Vancouver the AM. of the 4th inst., when Indians would be questioned in an effort to gather information in respect to this matter.

5. Accompanied by Cst.R.A.McDonald, a patrol was made to North Vancouver the AM. of the 4th inst., Cst.D.Payne of the Prov. Police was contacted who went with us to make enquiries into this complaint. It was decided that two brothers namely Walter & Leonard Campbell would first be questioned. These youths are Indians, who reside with their mother Mrs. Albert Hanson at the foot of Pemberton Ave., North Vancouver in a small shack on the waterfront. In calling at this address the writer was met at the door by Walter, this individual was in a very hostile mood, he refused to carry on conversation, and refused us admission...

CONTINUED...
REFUSED US ADMISSION to the house; in view of this subject's demeanour it was decided that a search of the house should be carried out, while the writer returned to North Vancouver, B.C., for a search warrant, the other members remained at the address. A search warrant was obtained from Mr. F.J. Bayfield and an immediate search was made of the premises referred to.

6. In conducting the search, nearly all the goods which were stolen from the School were recovered. Leonard Campbell admitted without any prompting at this time that he had been responsible in committing the offence, naming as his accomplice Donald Johnston, who resides on the Capilano Indian Reserve. Other articles recovered in making the search included an electric iron (new), two automobile Fog Lamps, Flashlights and a large quantity of cigarettes. These items had been stolen in B.E.E., at or from other business establishments in the North Vancouver District; the Provincial Police having received the complaints which were being investigated at the time.

7. Leonard Campbell was apprehended at this time, and with this prisoner a patrol was made to the Capilano Indian Reserve to the residence of Thomas Johnston. The subject Donald Johnston was questioned as to the part he had taken in committing the theft from the School, he readily admitted the fact that he had been implicated. A small quantity of part of the goods stolen was recovered from this address, which included some of the Br.Sugar, Butter, Lard etc. This subject was also apprehended and with Campbell was taken to the Prov.Police Detachment at North Vancouver where charges were laid by the Provincial Police in connection with the B.E.E. Theft from the North Vancouver Indian Residential School. The Provincial Police laid six other charges of B.E.E. Theft against these two, with respect to the theft from Garages, Stores & Parked cars which had occurred within the past few weeks.

8. Appearing in court on the 5th.inst., the cases against these Juveniles, who are each seventeen years of age, was transferred from the Juvenile court to the Police Court; they pleaded "Guilty" to all the charges, and were remanded for sentence to Monday the 10th.inst. On this date they again appeared, at which time Campbell was sentenced to serve one year in the Oakalla Gaol, Johnston was fined $50.00, and sentenced to time spent in custody, in default of payment of the fine to serve 60 days Oakalla Gaol.

9. Leonard Campbell had a previous record of B.E.E. having been sentenced to 18 mo. during 1946, this however, was reduced to 6 months on appeal. In passing sentence, undoubtedly the court took into consideration the fact that Johnston had no previous record, coupled with the fact that he is a juvenile.

CONVICTED

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Dear Sir:

I beg leave to apply to the Department of Indian Affairs for a grant of $530.00 to defray the cost of purchasing and installing two furnaces in our School, which has been heretofore heated by means of wood stoves; but these, besides giving a very irregular heat, are most dangerous especially with Indian children, who more than once came very near setting the building on fire.

Another thing to be considered is this. Firewood is rather scarce at the present time, and is likely to become more so in the near future, owing the growth of the City of North Vancouver, and very soon coal will be the only fuel used; so I think it will be more economical with the two furnaces than it would with about fifteen stoves.
Sir,-

I have the honor to forward herewith a letter, dated the 4th instant, No. 556/IO, received from Mr. Agent McDonald, of the Fraser Agency, B. C., with application, of the 22nd ultimo, addressed to him by the management of the Squamish Mission Indian Boarding school asking for permission to incur an expenditure of $530.00 in having two hot-air furnaces installed in the institution, the estimate of which will be found herewith. I concur in the statement made by the Agent that the furnaces would be more economical than are the large number of stoves now found necessary to properly heat the buildings during the cool months of the year besides being far safer and more satisfactory on the whole. Under the circumstances I would ask that the permission requested be granted.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Superintendent, B. C.

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, Ont.
Indian Office, New Westminster, B.C.,

Sir:—

I have the honor to enclose herewith an application in duplicate, dated the 22nd ultimo, received from the principal of the Squamish Mission Indian Boarding School, asking for a grant of $530.00 to defray the cost of purchasing and installing two furnaces in that Institution, as shown on estimate enclosed herewith.

There is no doubt but the furnaces would be more economical, safer, and more satisfactory than stoves. The estimated cost of the proposed improvements seems reasonable, and in view of the fact that this school has heretofore not received any assistance from the Department for buildings or improvements, and that the Management being unable to save anything from the present income of the Institution for such extra expenditures, I would therefore recommend the application to the favorable consideration of the Department.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Ever Ready Principal

In all the fire extinguishing apparatus manufactured by the Brandon Fire Engine Company, which includes hand fire extinguishers, warehouse engines, stand pipe system, chemical engines, the principal is the same. We do not use acid or soda, or any chemicals whatever; we use carbonic acid gas to put out fires, the water merely serving as a medium to carry the gas to the seat of the fire.

We throw out of all our extinguishers a stream twenty times as effective as any equal volume of water.

Our principal, in a few words, consisting in the application of liquid carbonic acid gas to a tank of water as a source of constant pressure and the utilization at the same time of the well known extinguishing powers of this gas.

The ordinary chemical engine, or chemical extinguisher, by the use of sulphuric acid and bicarbonate of soda, together with the water in the tank, is thrown out when the extinguisher is brought into action.

The Ever Ready extinguisher discharges nothing but clean water, charged with carbonic acid gas.

Every fireman in the land knows to his cost the damage done by corrosive discharges of the ordinary chemical.

The discharges from the Ever Ready does no damage, it will not soil the most delicate fabric.

Another Important Comparison

Once the ordinary chemical extinguisher is brought into action it must be thoroughly discharged before it can be reloaded. You can use any portion of the contents of the Ever Ready and save the remainder for future use.

What We Claim for the Ever Ready

We have no desire to disparage the merits of other extinguishers they are all more or less efficient, and have saved thousands of lives and millions of dollars from destruction by fire. We state, however, and are prepared to prove our statement, that we have the latest development of the carbonic acid gas extinguisher.

There has been practically no improvement in the carbonic acid gas extinguisher in a quarter of a century. All manufacturers still cling to the acid soda method of generating gas within the apparatus. This involves the discharge of a dirty dangerous corrosive mixture of carbonate and sulphate of soda, with generally a proportion of unneutralized sulphuric acid.

The Ever Ready discharges only carbonic acid gas dissolved in clean water, and claims to have all the advantages of the chemical stream without any chemicals.

We claim to have the only extinguisher in which the pressure is under absolute control. There is no extinguisher, except the Ever Ready that can be entirely discharged without the reduction of pressure, and the consequent loss of efficiency.

It is necessary in all acid soda extinguishers to wholly discharge the contents of the tank when once the acid is allowed to mix with the soda solution.

The pressure in every acid soda extinguisher is an unknown quantity, and varies with the purity and conditions of the chemicals used.

The pressure in the Ever Ready is under absolute control, and does not rise when the discharge is shut off to a dangerous point as in all acid soda chemicals. In fact it does not rise at all, but stands at the point it is set for whether the machine is discharging or not.

A Few Pertinent Facts

1. Since the discharge from the Ever Ready is a stream of gas to one of water, and as the gas is even more effective in extinguishing fires, it is evident that the volume of liquid to be discharged from an Ever Ready to extinguish fires is less than one twentieth of that required for a system using water only. This means one twentieth of the water damaged.

2. We have demonstrated that the Ever Ready system is the most efficient, the most reliable and the most up-to-date system of protection against fire that has ever been invented.

3. We use the very best material that money can buy in the construction of our apparatus.

4. Our system has the most unqualified endorsement of every practical fire fighter who has seen it.

5. All our apparatus is thoroughly tested before leaving the factory, and is installed by expert workmen.

6. Our apparatus is guaranteed to do all, and more than all we claim for it.

7. We will reduce your insurance premiums.

8. We send an expert to instruct you how to use it and test it.

Sir:

In accordance with your instructions of November 23rd 1910,
No. 889036, I have inspected all the Indian Boarding Schools within
this Inspectorate to see how far they comply with the specifications
in order to obtain the increased grant from the Department.

Generally speaking the dormitories of these schools have too
many pupils in them, but most of them will be able to comply with
the regulation in respect of air space by a slight re-arrangement
and placing some of the pupils in rooms now vacant or used for
other purposes.

None of the schools comply with the specifications in the
matter of taking the foul air off the floors through a heated
chimney stack, and the only one approaching this is the school at
Alberni, which has a system of ventilators in the base boards in
the class rooms and dormitories, and the windows being kept open
for the entrance of fresh air. The other schools depend entirely
upon the open windows and, in some instances, ventilating trap-doors
in the ceilings of the dormitories only.

As regards hospital accommodation, all the schools are well
equipped in this respect, having separate rooms for this purpose
and in some instances outside buildings.

All the schools have sufficient land for farming or gardening
where it is necessary that these occupations should be taught,
and some of them have carpenter-shops, where instructions are given
in the rudimentary principles of house building and general car-
penter work is given.

Dear Sir:

I beg to write you confidentially about my Financial Statement. So far—That is for 3 years—I have succeeded with the Grant and some little donations to cover my expenses; but this past year, owing to the high cost of living, I could not.

Still this I would not mind so much were it not for some repairs that must be done immediately. There are the foundation of school which threaten to collapse and the drain for the waste water. Two weeks ago I had a carpenter around the building and he said that approximately the job would cost $200.00, and I have not the first cent to begin with, since I am behind.

What shall I do? Borrow at 5%? This I cannot do, for I do not want to run into debt.

Well, dear Sir, let me make an appeal to the generosity of the Department to help me in such bad straits. I know they cannot raise the Grant of our school without raising the others, but this help they will not refuse to a poor man who has devoted nearly all his life to the welfare of the Indians and felt so badly the lack of funds at the present time.

Hoping my humble request shall be granted and thanking you before hand I remain

Your very respectfully,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to repairs to the foundation and sewerage system of the Squamish Mission Indian boarding school.

I regret that our appropriation is so limited, that it is difficult to find funds for these and many other needed improvements. Dear Sirs,

We respectfully bring to your notice a few details regarding this Company's operations.

**Fire Extinguisher Inspection and Re-charging**

This branch of our services is perhaps the most important, as an extinguisher, no matter its original cost, is absolutely worthless should it fail to operate at the critical moment, when called on to extinguish a fire in the early stages.

Let us mention some of the reasons why extinguishers have on very numerous occasions fallen down when most urgently needed:

1. Improperly charged.
2. Charged when installed, no attention after.
3. Discharged at a fire and re-charging overlooked.

Our service takes care of such matters and gives the best possible assurance that your extinguishers are always in good working condition and ready for all emergencies on the moment.

This Company's service seal and charge labels attached to extinguishers, are officially recognized and thoroughly endorsed by Underwriters and Fire Department Officials. Seals are so adjusted as to make it an impossibility for any person to tamper with extinguishers without breaking the seal. Labels show at a glance the condition at all times.

Enclosed rate card proves that we can give this at a cost that is actually less than you can re-charge extinguishers yourself, not counting your employees time on same. In addition to this you are assured that they are looked after in the proper manner and thoroughly inspected every three months. Reverend Sister:

Regarding inspection made this afternoon, in company with the Fire Chief, we beg to make a report covering the Fire Protection, and respectfully submit suggestions as follows:

**FIRE ALARM GONGS:** In very poor condition. Wiring in places defective and circuits installed in series, making upper gongs weak.

The whole system should be re-wired and present electric light switches replaced by standard Fire Alarm Switches.

At least two additional gongs should be installed, as those on upper floors are small, and we very much doubt if the children would be awakened by them in an emergency.

**FIRE EXTINGUISHERS:** In good condition but need re-charging. These extinguishers must be re-charged periodically to be efficient and ready for instant action.

**FIRE HOSE:** The fabric of same is very much deteriorated. Should be replaced by hose of less bulk. Present size is very heavy and would prove most difficult for a Sister or Child to handle in case of fire.

**FIRE ESCAPES:** There are no outside escapes. The only way of exit is down the stairway. Position of this stairway, through the centre of the building, would make this a very risky way of exit in case of fire, as the chances are that smoke and flames would make descent impossible. Outside escapes should be provided, two from the Girls' Dormitory and one from the Boys'. Either permanent stairway escapes, or automatic ladders could be used.

As suggested by you, we phoned Mr. C.C. Perry, who advised our writing you covering a requisition regarding this matter. We are sending Mr. Perry a copy of this letter also.

Thanking you for courtesies extended the writer, we remain,

Yours respectfully,

Fire-Gun as a Protection against Fire Danger

FIRE-GUN is a hand fire extinguisher. It puts out little fires before they get to be big ones. The small fire is the great menace. Almost invariably the big fire comes from a little one. Where that danger exists FIRE-GUN should be on guard.

In FIRE-GUN we have produced a new liquid pump which is positively double acting from the first stroke until it is absolutely empty, thereby overcoming the great defect found in others which are only double acting when nearly full.

The mechanical construction of FIRE-GUN is so perfect that it never pumps air. It never splutters or dribbles, but shoots a solid stream thirty or forty feet. FIRE-GUN is built to stand rough usage. All parts are so strong and well protected that it never leaks or fails to operate. New from the factory or after standing for years, it shoots a faster, steadier stream than any other hand extinguisher.

After all, the supreme test is, how quickly can the fluid be shot into a fire. Due to the reliability of our pump and its perfect mechanical construction, FIRE GUN is emptied in about half the number of strokes required by any other one quart type extinguisher.

FIRE-GUN FLUID is effective where water is useless. It will not deteriorate, is a non-conductor of electricity, does not freeze at 50 degrees below zero, and will not damage machinery or delicate fabrics.

Immediately it strikes the heat it forms a heavy blanket of non-combustible gas which crowds out the air and puts out the fire. It is, therefore, especially effective on burning liquids such as gasoline, kerosene, kitchen fires of burning fats, etc., or rapidly burning materials, such as celluloid; of fabrics, such as cotton-burlap and cloth; or combination of these, such as waste saturated with oil; and on all electrical fires.

Ottawa, March 22nd, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, enclosing correspondence which you received from the Fire Protection & Supply Co., Vancouver, regarding the fire equipment at the Squamish Indian Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have the 6 fire extinguishers which are in use re-charged and placed in good condition. You should also arrange to have the fire alarm gongs thoroughly overhauled and any repairs required carried out. If necessary, the system should be re-wired and 2 additional gongs installed on the upper floors to replace the present gongs which are too small for the purpose.

Regarding fire hose, I beg to say that the Department will be prepared to authorize the supply of the quantity of hose considered absolutely necessary for the purpose, also any nozzles, couplings, etc., required.

In the carrying out of the above repairs, alterations and purchase of new fire equipment, the cost should be kept down to the lowest possible point, and in the making of any purchases competitive prices should be obtained. We are not prepared to authorize a regular inspection service.

Regarding the fire escapes, I beg to refer you to official letter of December 30th, last, in which you were requested to make a recommendation to the Department after securing an estimate of the cost of the fire escapes desired.

You should arrange to have the extinguishers, fire gongs and fire hose overhauled and placed in good condition as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Following our conversation of August 29th we have interviewed Fire Chief Murphy, of North Vancouver, regarding St. Paul's School Fire Protection.

Regarding a letter mailed to you, by the Chief, on July 6th we have much pleasure in quoting as follows:

1. Fire hose in dining room 50 ft. 2 inch rubber lined... $30.00

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 23rd re condition of fire equipment in the Squamish Mission Boarding School, after inspecting same I would recommend the following.

(1) That new fire hose be installed - as the present is worn out.
(2) The nozzle connected to the present hose be repaired, located near basement door.
(3) That a shut-off nozzle be used in the dining-room.
(4) That a hose reel be installed on the wall in the dining-room.
(5) That a 3 gallon soda and acid extinguisher be installed in the kitchen and the same on the second floor on the main stair-way and also one in the laundry.

Yours respectfully,

(sgd) W. Murphy.

Chief of Fire Department.
Referring to that portion of your letter dated March 2nd, No.167-1-5, being the third paragraph thereof, having reference to the proposed supplying of a quantity of hose, nozzles, couplings etc., absolutely necessary for the purpose of fighting fire in the Squamish Mission Indian Boarding School, at North Vancouver, I have the honour to inform you that the Chief of the Fire Department, North Vancouver was requested to make a recommendation as to what he would consider to be absolutely necessary in this connection. I would recommend that the purchase of the material suggested in the two letters be authorized in due course.

Your obedient servant,

Reverend and dear Father:

Enclosed please find the list of repairs and other articles urgently needed at the Squamish Boarding School.

I did not mention the scale to Rev. Father Guy, but as the children must be weighed occasionally during the year, it is quite a nuisance to have to take them to one of the stores of North Vancouver in order to have them weighed.

Dear Sir:

In response to your letter of the 18th instant, I have inspected the building and plumbing work referred to.

The floor of the building has recently been repaired and is approximately 1/4 inches out of level at the water intake which would naturally trap the water, causing it to freeze and burst the pipe.

Re Plumbing:
I find the laundry tubs at the South east end of the building to be 1/2 inch out of level, which would trap the water making it impossible to drain the pipes.

On the North east side I find that the plumber has put in the tubs running with the floor, while being approximately 1/2 inches out of level forms a trap, causing the pipes to burst when frozen.

There is plenty of fall to the waste pipe to carry off the water and they are properly vented.

Mr. Young claims that the floor has settled since he put in these tubs, and although he claims the fault is not his, he is willing to put the plumbing in good condition providing the floor is made level.

Yours truly,

(signed) J.W. Fugler,

Sir,

I have the honour to transmit herewith Voucher No.540, attached to which is an account of the Roberton-Godson Co., Ltd., of Vancouver, B.C., for twelve laundry traps, two wood wringer boards, two wringers and twenty-four wash tray bibs connected with the traps, the installing of the same, including waste and traps, at the Squamish Indian Mission Boarding School, at North Vancouver.

I would inform you that a dispute arose between the school authorities and this Company, after the completion of the work, which called for a report from the plumbing and building inspector of the City of North Vancouver. It had been found following the installation of the traps, that portions of the plumbing had been frozen and pipes burst; and upon investigation it was discovered that while two small sags were found in the pipe which prevented the pipes from emptying when the water was turned off during the frosty period, it was also found that the reason for the pipes sagging in this way was that a new floor had been put in by the school authorities in the laundry room, immediately prior to the installation of the traps, which were found to be half an inch out of level at the south-east end of the room, being one and a quarter inches out of level on the north-east side, thus forming traps in the piping which caused them to burst. This condition has now been corrected, and I am submitting herewith the account for the same, together with a copy of the inspector's report and an abstract of tenders, which were asked for by Mr. School-Inspector Cairns and myself, in personal interviews with the companies tendering. I would recommend payment of the account.

Your obedient servant,

C.G. Perry,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Your circular dated Oct. 6th reached me in due time. In reply I beg to say that there are two fire escapes in the girls' dormitory, the doors of which are not fastened and open outside, besides two staircases.

For the boys' dormitories there is only one fire escape located in the big boys' dormitory, with two windows opening on it. The little boys' dormitory is only five spaces from this fire escape, it is true; but in case of emergency another fire escape would be needed.

We have a sufficient number of fire extinguishers set at strategic places and the children are drilled occasionally. Our engaged man sleeps in a cottage not far from the main building and has a telephone.

Before retiring, that is about 10 o'clock, two Sisters visit the basement, furnace and kitchen. Besides, winter not being very severe in B.C., we very seldom keep fire going during the night.

Hoping that these explanations will prove satisfactory, I am, dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Sir:

I beg to refer to Departmental letter No. 167-1-5 dated November 22nd, 1927, in which authority was granted for the erection of an additional fire escape at the Squamish Indian Residential School at a cost of approximately $75.00. Subsequently Vouchers Nos. 2917, 2918, 2986 and 2987 were sent to the Department for the payment of labor performed on this job, the cost of which amounted to $52.75.

The material for this escape which was of wooden construction was taken from the scaffolding and left over lumber from the construction of the new Community Hall which otherwise may have been left and difficult to dispose of. The cost of the material would amount to $22.25 under ordinary circumstances if purchased especially for this work. The amount therefore has been covered by Voucher No. 3058 herewith to be credited to the Squamish Band of Indians Trust account No. 54 and to be charged against the School Vote and transferred by the Department to the Squamish Fund. Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter of the 8th March instant, No. 167-1-5, covering cheque for $450 sent to me for the wages in connection with the construction of the Squamish Indian Residential School portion of a joint sewerage disposal system with the Squamish Auditorium Building through the Mission Reserve No. 1, to the City of North Vancouver sewer outfall. In this connection I beg to transmit herewith Voucher No. 3056, attached to which are returns of labor for the weeks ending February 25th, March 10th, and March 17th, amounting to a total of $429.35 leaving an unexpended balance to date of $10.65, which amount is being returned here-with by Bank Draft No. 342, as the Fiscal Year closes in a few days.

When the sewerage work was recommended, it was estimated that the cost would be approximately $600.00, $450.00 of which would be charged against the Schools Vote and $150.00 against the Squamish Auditorium building. The latter connection was made at a less cost than estimated viz: $130.30. The School portion, however, will exceed the amount asked for, for when the estimate was given the City Engineer gave Mr. Shockley to understand that excavation to about five (5) feet depth only would be necessary whereas on proceeding with the undertaking no less than twelve feet were found necessary to excavate, several feet of depth of which excavation was through hard compressed clay almost amounting to hardpan which, with boulders to remove, made the work much more difficult and protracted.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
March 26, 1928.

It is expected that the work will be finished by about March 28th. - 29th., but the cost will exceed the estimate by

1. Cost of vitrified pipe, as per Voucher 3051 - $134.50
2. Cost of cement, as per Voucher No. 3050 - $7.60
3. Cost of labor from March 19th. to 24th. as per return herewith, Voucher No. 3057 - $279.20
4. Also cost of labor for March 26th. to about March 28th.)

The Vouchers for the pipe and cement are sent herewith numbered 3051 and 3050. The labor returns for the week ended March 24th. are sent herewith attached to Voucher numbered 3057. I shall thank the Department to have the cheque sent to me for labor payments as soon as possible.

I trust that the action taken to carry the work through to completion as early as possible will be approved. To have left the sewer half-completed would have greatly increased the menace caused by the inundation by sewerage from the boarding school of a considerable portion of the residential part of Squamish Reserve, as well as leave dangerous excavation open with menace of accidents.

Your obedient servant,

(C.C. Perry)
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter dated August 2nd., No.467-1-4, with reference, in particular, to a requisition made for six additional desks for the Squamish Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that I consider these desks necessary in order to insure uniformity in the classrooms, as the children boarding in the Residential School and the pupils of the Indian Day School are mixed in the different rooms according to the grades they are in. The new building which is being used as a Day School accommodates some ten or twelve pupils of the Residential School (Beginners) while the other two classrooms in the Residential School take all pupils from grade 2. to grade 8. Besides this some would-be boarders will have to content themselves with being day pupils only, as there is no room available for them in the Residential School.

The desks asked for will be No.5, and would cost $6.50 each and are manufactured by the East Pipe and Foundry Co., Vancouver, the same firm that supplied the desks under competitive tender as previously supplied.

Laundry:

There are two small boilers heated by a small fire. The cement in which these boilers are set is badly cracked. There are 12 tubs for washing the children's clothes. All the work is done by hand. The drying room is heated by a very small box heater. A much larger heater is very badly needed. This would not cost very much, and would help to dry the clothes in a much more satisfactory manner.

Kitchen:

The kitchen is clean. A new kitchen range is required. The old one is now worn out. The one supplied should be of modern design with warming ovens and large enough to supply the needs of about sixty people.

Drainage:

The school is connected by sewerage pipes with the North Vancouver system. The bath accommodation is very poor indeed. There is only one bath on each side, (one for boys and one for girls). This only permits of a child having a bath once in two weeks which I do not consider sufficient. At the same time, I do not quite see where more baths could be put without building.

The toilet system is worse even than that of the baths. The boys' toilets are of a very ancient design. They are safe enough from a health point of view; but there is no toilet near the boys' dormitory. They have to go down to the basement even at night.

The wash rooms on girls' and boys' sides are kept very clean.

Games: The children play all sorts of games. There is a covered shed for the boys. I would recommend that a swing and two climbing ropes be authorized. All that is wanted is about 50 feet of thick rope. The swing can be made at the school.

Sir-

I beg to report that the enclosed resolution of the Squamish Indian Council was discussed but was not put to the vote. I pointed out that there were no funds available at the present time for a new school and that the Department was fully aware of conditions at the School and the necessity for a new one when possible, but they would have to carry on for the time being.

It is no more a fire trap now than it has ever been. All precautions are taken against fire and a new furnace was installed recently.

Some of the Council reported that the roof was unsafe. Would it be possible to have the Public Works Department make an examination of it? I cannot say personally whether there is any danger, but I think it is largely imaginary.

Of course many things could be pointed out as needing repair or re-building, if funds were available.

Regarding the question of returning children home who have been brought from other agencies to this School, the children have been recruited from various places, but on the other hand, some of the Squamish Indians are attending other schools. Sir:

Dear Sir:

Re: Inspection Furnaces, etc., at the
Indian Industrial School, North Vancouver, B.C.

On August 16th I inspected the heating plant of the above
building. This plant consists of three hot air furnaces, as
follows:

1 Sunbeam of 55,000 ft. capacity,
1 Enterprise of 30,000 ft. capacity,
1 Vulcan of 30,000 ft. capacity.

These furnaces are in a very fair state of repair, but under
the conditions which they are installed they would be subjected
to a large amount of corrosion, as the basement floor is of
a clayey nature and is not cemented.

On the Enterprise furnace the outside shell had been cut out
to allow the smoke pipe to pass through, and the hole had not
afterwards been stopped up. There were also some parts of this
casing coming open. I pointed this out to the attendant and he
promised that he would get some sheet asbestos and cover them
up. There were also some small cracks in the front, which I
recommended to be stopped and filled with furnace cement.

The Vulcan furnace is new and in good condition, but there has
been a new bunker built, one wall of which is much too close to
this furnace. I pointed this out to the attendant and Mother
Superior and they promised to remove it to a new position and
cover the side nearest the furnace with some old sheet iron
which was on the premises. The smoke pipe from this furnace is
too close to the woodwork, unless it is covered with sheet
asbestos, which I was promised would be done at once.

The Sunbeam furnace is in good condition, except the firebars,
and a new set of these have been ordered.

This is a very old school, constructed of wood, and every
precaution must be taken to prevent fire. The whole place is
in a very clean condition, but has a damp smell which the
openings left in the furnace casings must have conveyed up to
the building.

The approximate cost of materials for repairs mentioned above
is Ten Dollars ($10.00).

Yours respectfully,

T. J. Arnall
Engineer.

Dear Sister Superior,

At your inquiry, we have made a thorough examination of the furnace and equipment in the East wing of the school.

The furnace is past repair, prematurely, owing to an unbalanced system. The existing pipes etc., expanded end not fit for further use. I would point out that the pipes etc., are the original and probably have done duty to three or more replacement furnaces. It is definitely clear, that it never has at any time given proper warmth for the amount of fuel used. We suggest moving the many improvements you are making also enlarging of class rooms, etc., that it is very necessary that a planned new heating system be installed.

A larger supply of warm air to the class rooms and dormitory, also return air from same. The wooden cold air duct from class room taken out and replaced with a larger capacity metal duct to be transferred to dormitory, and the special duct over sawdust bins and angle toward breezeway at point of entry into class room to not interfere with heavy load around furnace. A larger supply to class room, and a special duct vertical to Dormitory bringing in heat and distributing heat north and south directions. A duplicate furnace to the one installed last year in the East wing a Sunbeam #1048 all cast 24" firepot will handle the efficiently. Replace other existing leaders with piping and angles etc. Also new and larger return air pipe from ducts to furnace. New heavy 22 Gge smoke pipes, and angles.

Our estimate for this job with complete coal burning equipment supplied but left on of furnace and your sawdust burner installed with new fire-bricks $7465.00 Seven hundred forty eight dollars.

As there is considerable work to be done on this job and school opening very soon we would appreciate your earliest reply as we will give you precedence so has to complete before school opening.

Yours Very Truly
Tomlinson Heating & Sheet Metal.

Ottawa, January 31, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, regarding the installing of a new furnace to replace the "Sunbeam" furnace in use at the Squamish Indian Residential School. In this connection it is noted that you have arranged with the Marshall-Wells Company to install a new furnace at a cost of $90.00. Your action in this matter is approved. I would request that you forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the furnace, before the middle of March, next, in order that payment can be made from our Appropriation for the current fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
203-6 Rogers Bldg.,
Vancouver, B. C.
With regard to the lack of proper accommodation for the senior pupils, I beg to report that in my opinion no time should be lost in changing the partitions in the upper part of the new manual training and auditorium building. All that is necessary is to move the present partition between the manual training shop ten or twelve feet over to the side on which the primary room is located, and then move the partition of the new senior room to a position at right angles to about ten feet into the manual training shop from the position formerly occupied by the partition between the manual training shop and the primary room. These moves which would not cost much will give two good sized classrooms and a slightly smaller manual training shop than we have at present. Why this was not done at first, a couple of years ago when the senior pupils were brought from the old building I do not know. The Indian Agent appears to have arranged for the erection of this and another partition, whose very single examination of the building would have shown that no such partitions should ever have been erected. Neither he nor the Department consulted me in this matter and the consequent result is that money will now be required to undo the mischief then carried out. THIS MATTER IS VITAL AND NEEDS ATTENTION BEFORE THE HOT WEATHER. The other new partition erected by the instructions of the Indian Agent in what was the old senior classroom, see Paragraphs 2 and 3 of my report on this school under date of January 25th and 26th, 1932, should be taken out at once and the room used as a classroom for the home study of the resident boys. The necessary fire escape ladder recommended in paragraph 3 of the same report has not been constructed and will not be needed when this room returns to a classroom, as it will not be then any more of a fire trap than the rest of this old school. The paragraphs mentioned above are those on the page of my last report headed Buildings.

A new bath and toilet should be constructed on the boys' side in a room off the boys' dormitory formerly used by one of the staff. None of these recommendations will run into large sums of money. Much of the work can be done by the boys under a well qualified manual training instructor, and I would ask that this be considered in making an appointment to such a position in the future, should the Department agree with me in my recommendation under the heading of manual training below.

Fire Protection: There are two hydrants with hose,
which has been tested. There are also eight chemical extinguishers, and a number of fire buckets. The extinguishers have been tested. THE FIRE BUCKETS WERE EMPTY when I visited the school. On the occasion of my last inspection, it was found that these buckets were empty, and I recommended that they be filled with water, and in some cases sand. I also recommended that the shelves on which these buckets rested should be lowered so that the big children could lift the buckets off the shelves and use them in case of fire, which they could not do able to do at present as the shelves are too high. This was all reported to the Department in January 1932; but no action seems to have been taken. IT IS VERY IMPORTANT THAT THE FIRE RISK BE REDUCED AT THIS SCHOOL. It is a very old building, and if it ever takes fire I do not believe that much could be done to save it, even with modern engines. It is, therefore, very important that extinguishers and buckets be kept charged and available in case of the discovery of the beginning stages of fire. There are four fire gongs. Fire drills are held regularly and that carried out when I visited the school was quite satisfactory. The Fire Chief visits the school from time to time.

Dormitories: All the dormitories are kept in a perfectly neat and clean condition. I have made some recommendations above as to the creation of two new dormitories for the children, one boys' and one girls', in the rooms used up to this as dormitories for the Sisters of the Child Jesus, who were not actually teaching in this school and who have now gone to their new Convent.

I notice that there are four beds in which two children sleep together. These eight small children should under the rules of the Department have eight beds, and I would ask the Department to enforce this very necessary rule.
Sir:

Mr. Inspector Barry, in a report on his inspection, in March, last, of the Squamish Indian Residential School, draws attention to the lack of proper accommodation for the senior pupils. He states that changes should be made in the partitions in the upper part of the new manual training and auditorium building. It appears that all that is necessary is to move the present partition between the manual training shop approximately twelve feet into the boys' side on which the primary room is located and to move the partition of the new senior room to a position at right angles and about ten feet into the manual training shop, from the position formerly occupied by the partition between the manual training shop and the primary room. The moving of these partitions, which, it is considered, could be carried out with little expense, would give two good-sized classrooms and a slightly smaller manual training shop. Further, it appears that a partition which was erected in what was the old senior classroom should be removed and this room used as a classroom for the home study of the resident boys.

The Department does not appear to have any record regarding the installing of the partitions as at present located. It is considered that the change in location of these partitions, as outlined above, should be carried out at the earliest possible date, before the hot weather begins. No doubt, the work could be performed by the older boys, under the supervision of the manual training instructor, without expense to the Department. Should the boys be unable to do this work, I would request that you furnish the Department, as soon as possible, with an estimate of the cost.

It is recommended that a new bath and toilet be constructed on the boys' side, in a room off the boys' dormitory, formerly used by one of the staff. The Inspector states that the greater part of the work could be done by the boys, under the manual training instructor. You might inform the Department as to the cost of any materials and any outside labour required in installing the bath and toilet.

I may add that we have no funds specially provided for alterations or repairs at this school, and, if any large expense is necessary in the moving of the partitions or the installing of the bath and toilet, we would not be prepared to authorize same.

Mr. Barry found that the fire buckets were empty when he visited the school. He recommends, also, that

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
203-6 Rogers Bldg.,
Vancouver, B. C.
the shelves on which these buckets rest be lowered, so that, in the event of fire, the older children could lift the buckets off the shelves - which they are not able to do, as at present the shelves are too high. The boys of the manual training class should be able to lower these shelves to the right height, and you should instruct the Principal and staff to see that the fire buckets are kept filled with water and, in some cases, sand, in order that they will be ready for immediate use. It is very important that all steps be taken to reduce fire risk in this school. The Department will rely on you to see that the staff keep all fire equipment in good condition and ready for use.

Regarding the dormitories, the Inspector states he noticed that there were four beds in which two children sleep together. There should be a separate bed provided for each child, and I would request that you draw this matter to the attention of the Principal. She should arrange, as soon as possible, to supply the extra beds required.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant with reference to Mr. Barry's report on the Squamish Residential School at North Vancouver.

The question of moving the partitions in the auditorium building was discussed with the Reverend Mother Principal some time ago but she was not enthusiastic about it. However this is a very small alteration and will be attended to if the Principal still wishes it.

As it is contemplated to dispense with the services of the present manual training instructor, I respectfully suggest that no alterations be made by him at the present time. While at Sechelt the boys who have had only a year or two training would be quite capable of doing this work, the Squamish boys could not do it.

Regarding Paragraph 3, I reported two years ago that bathing facilities at the school both on the boys' and girls' side were inadequate and recommended shower baths such as we installed at Sechelt. They have proved a great success there and the Principal said every pupil in the school could have a daily bath in forty minutes, whereas bath-tubs mean practically a day's work and consequently they are not taken as frequently as they should be. I have also been advised that two children use the same bath water sometimes, which is most unsatisfactory.

I regret I can not agree with the Inspector that "the greater part of the work could be done by the boys". They know little about carpentry and nothing about plumbing and even the manual training instructor can not do plumbing. On account of the cost of installing new plumbing fixtures in this old school, you ruled against the proposed shower baths and presumably such ruling would apply also with regard to baths and toilets.

Regarding the fire buckets, these shelves will be lowered and the Reverend Principal advised to appoint some one to see that they are always filled. The Fire Department's inspector at North Vancouver who visits this school regularly when he visits the public schools, says these fire buckets are the only ones in the City of North Vancouver schools and he doubts their usefulness.....

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
usefulness. He says sand would not be advisable as it is useful only in garages and places where gasoline fires occur, but in any fire at this school it would have little effect. The fire extinguishers are re-filled and kept in thorough good order at all times and the school is only a few hundred yards from the fire hall.

With regard to the last paragraph, this was taken up with the Reverend Principal before Mr. Barry visited the school and I was advised that it was only a temporary arrangement which has been adjusted.

The various partitions which the Inspector found in the main school were built by the school janitor without expense to the Department.

The Reverend Sister Mary Amy, Principal, has recently built an exceptionally fine building which completely eclipses the school in every way. This building I understand is used as a home by the sisters who teach at the school. They formerly lived at the school and their removal has made extra space available in the school building for more pupils. I believe Inspector Barry has recommended increasing the pupilage to seventy, but this should be given the most careful consideration as there are several reasons why it would be inadvisable. I presume the Department would make full investigation before granting any such increase.

Inspector Barry might call on me occasionally when he visits schools in this Agency and discuss things before he makes his reports so that matters which have already been dealt with by the Department are not reported again as new business, causing confusion and unnecessary correspondence.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant I regret that there has been some delay in paying the accounts to which you refer.

As the Squamish Residential School is not owned by the Department it is necessary to secure an Order-in-Council before payment can be made of expenditure incurred for repairs and improvements.

As you are aware we agreed to allow $350.00 toward the cost of installing the new showers at this school. An Order-in-Council has recently been received for this amount and a cheque for $350.00 is being forwarded to the Fred Welsh Company. The statement forwarded with your account showed that the total cost of the showers was $400.00. As stated above the Department is paying $350.00 of this amount and returning, unaided, the account of the Reliance Lumber Company.

It is considered, in view of the information contained in your letter of September 20 last, that the Principal will be quite willing to pay $54.30 from school funds.

Yours truly,
